Translated: 6.20. by consuming yoga in the stages in which the unrighteous mind becomes humble and in the stages in which himself becomes satisfied in himself when he sees himself in himself.

Original: 6.21 When he (the Yogi) feels that Infinite Bliss which can be grasped by the (pure) intellect and which transcends the senses, and established wherein he never moves from the Reality.
Translated: 6.21 The pleasure which is eternal, eternal and buddhist, the pleasure in which it experiences and in which it is located, this meditative never again deviates by wisdom.

Original: 6.22 Which, having obtained, he thinks there is no other gain superior to it; wherein estabished, he is not moved even by heavy sorrow.
Translated: 6:22 And no other benefit comes to his beliefs more than that which is beneficial when it is achieved; and when it is in it, it is not distracted by great suffering.

Original: 6.23 Let that be known by the name of Yoga, the severance from union with pain. This Yoga should be practised with determination and with an undesponding mind.
Translated: 6.23 It is the coincidence of the sadness, it must know by the name of ‘young’ (the yoga which is the purpose of the meditation) that the practice of the meditation must do with the intelligence not raised.

Translated: 6.24 All the desires arising from resolutions are free of charge and by mind the intellectual community in equal possession from all sides.

Original: 6.26 From whatever cause the restless and unsteady mind wanders away, from that let him restrain it and bring it under the control of the Self alone.
Translated: 6:26 It is the chicked and unstable mind for which reasons (in matters) it speaks, to limit it, and to put it in the hands of the Spirit, that is, to establish it in the Spirit.

Original: 6.27 Supreme Bliss verily comes to this Yogi whose mind is ite peaceful, whose passion is ieted, who has become Brahman and who is free from sin.
Translated: 6:27 Those whose mind is peaceful, who is sinless, and whose righteousness is calmed, this universally formed yogi shall receive the best pleasure.

Original: 6.28 The Yogi, always engaging the mind thus (in the practice of Yoga), freed from sins, easily enjoys the Infinite Bliss of contact with Brahman (the Eternal).
Translated: 6.28 Thus, the sinless yogi, who is able to stabilize the mind forever in the soul, enjoys the ultimate pleasure of the universe.

Original: 6.29 With the mind harmonised by Yoga he sees the Self abiding in all beings and all beings in the Self; he sees the same everywhere.
6.30 He who sees Me everywhere and sees everything in Me, he never becomes separated from Me, nor do I become separated from him.
Translated: The man who sees me everywhere and sees me everywhere, for him I would not be destroyed (i.e. for him I would not be away) and he would not be apart from me.

Original: 6.31 He who, being established in unity, worships Me Who dwells in all beings, that Yogi abides in Me, whatever may be his mode of living.
Translated: 6:31 Whoever humbles me in all the spirits which are located in the unity of man, he is in me in all kinds of purification (rheting).

Original: 6.32 He who, through the likeness of the Self, O Arjuna, sees eality everywhere, be it pleasure or pain, he is regarded as the highest Yogi.
Translated: 6:32 O Arjuna, the man who sees all things like him, whether he is pleasant or sad, he is considered the ultimate yogi.

Original: 6.33 Arjuna said  This Yoga of eanimity taught by Thee, O Krishna, I do not see its steady continuance, because of the restlessness (of the mind).
Translated: 6:33.Arjuna said, “O Madhusudan, which this communal yoga you said, I do not see its eternal position because of the mind’s chunchle.

Original: 6.34 The mind verily is restless, turbulent, strong and unyielding, O Krishna: I deem it as difficult to control it as to control the wind.
Translated: 6:34 For, o Krishna, this mind is cheerful and pronounced, and strong and strong; I consider its praise as evil as the air.

Original: 6.35 The Blessed Lord said  Undoubtedly, O mighty-armed Arjuna, the mind is difficult to control and restless; but by practice and by dispassion it may be restrained.
Translated: 6:35 And the Lord says, “Mahabao, the mind will be uncertain and hardly in possession; but, o Kanti-Son, it can be in possession by practice and waragya.

Original: 6.36 I think Yoga is hard to be attained by one of uncontrolled self, but the self-controlled and striving one can attain to it by the (proper) means.
Translated: It is difficult to get yoga by the man of the untouched mind, but it is possible to get yoga by the attempting man of the good mind, this is not mine.

Original: 6.37 Arjuna said  He who is unable to control himself though he has the faith, and whose mind wanders away from Yoga, what end does he, having failed to attain perfection in Yoga, mee,t O Krishna?
Translated: 6:37 And Arjuna said, O Kṛṣṇa, whose mind has been driven by yoga, what speed does he get without obtaining the proof of such unfulfilled effort, the honorable man of yoga?

Original: Swami Sivananda did not comment on this sloka
Translated: 6:38 O Mabbah, does he not be destroyed in the way of the universe, corrupt by both sides, like the wicked and wicked men?

Original: 6.39 This doubt of mine, O Krishna, do Thou dispel completely; because it is not possible for any but Thee to dispel this doubt.
Translated: 6:39 O Kṛṣṇa, you are the one who is worthy to freely deceive this doubt; for no other than you is possible to find the one who deceives this doubt.

Original: 6.40 The Blessed Lord said  O Arjuna, neither in this world, nor in the next world is there destruction for him; none, verily, who does good, O My son, ever comes to grief.
Translated: 6:40 And the Lord said, “O Pharat, that man is not destroyed in this people nor in the people; O Tate, no one who is doing good works is unfortunate.

Original: 6.41 Having attained to the worlds of the righteous and having dwelt there for everlasting years, he who fell from Yoga is rorn in a house of the pure and wealthy.
Translated: 6.41 The unfair man, by receiving the people of the nobles, lives there for a long time and is born in the house of rich men with pure behavior.

Original: 6.42 Or he is born in a family of even the wise Yogis; verily a birth like this is very difficult to obtain in this world.
Translated: 6:42. or it is born in the whole of the wise men, but this kind of birth is undoubtedly very rare among this people.

Original: 6.43 Thee he comes in touch with the knowledge acired in his former body and strives more than before for perfection, O Arjuna.
Translated: O Corinthians, that man, fulfilling with the knowledge acquired there in the former body, tries even more for yoga.

Original: 6.44 By that very former practice he is borne on in spite of himself. Even he who merely wishes to know Yoga goes beyond the Brahmic word.
Translated: 6.44. because of the same pre-exercise, it is attracted to the disappointed yoga; the only curiosity of yoga is the discourse of the wordbrahma.

Original: 6.45 But the Yogi who strives with assiduity, purified of sins and perfected gradually through many births, reaches the highest goal.
Translated: 6:45. but whoever tries with effort, the yogi, purified from all sins and proven from many births, then achieves the ultimate speed.

Original: 6.46 The Yogi is thought to be superior to the ascetics and even superior to men of knowledge (obtained through the study of scriptures); he is also superior to men of action; therefore be thou a Yogi, O Arjuna.
Translated: 6:46 For the yogi is better than the taps, and it is considered better than the wise, and the yogi is better than those who do the works, so ye, Arjuna, be the yogi.

Original: 6.47 And among all the Yogis he who, full of faith and with his inner self merged in Me, worships Me is deemed by Me to be the most devout.
Translated: 6:47 In all the youths, whatever the honourable yogi is in me from the inner spirit (i.e. from the spirit of unity), he is the best (the best) to me.

Original: 7.1 The Blessed Lord said  O Arjuna, hear how you shall without doubt know Me fully, with the mind intent on Me, practising Yoga and taking refuge in Me.
Translated: 7:1 O Parta, with unstained minds in me, and practicing yoga, as you will know me in general, without any doubt, he will hear.

Original: 7.2 I shall declare to thee in full this knowledge combined with realisation, after knowing which nothing more here remains to be known.
Translated: 7:2 And I will specially tell you this knowledge, including knowledge, which, knowing it, no longer remains here (in the world) any knowledgeable.

Original: 7.3 Among thousands of men, one perchance strives for perfection; even among those successful strivers, only one perchance knows Me in essence.
Translated: 7.3 In thousands of men no man tries to prove perfection, and even in those trivial seekers no man knows me wisely.

Original: 7.4 Earth, water, fire, air, ether, mind, intellect and egoism  thus is My Nature divided eightfold.
Translated: Earth, water, fire, air and heaven and mind, wisdom and ego – this is my nature divided in eight kinds.

Original: 7.5 This is the inferior Prakriti, O mighty-armed (Arjuna); know thou as different from it My higher Prakriti (Nature), the very life-element, by which this world is upheld.
Translated: 7:5 O great, this is unnatural; know my living supernatural that differs from it, by which it is possessed.

Original: 7.6 Know that these two (Natures) are the womb of all beings. So I am the source and dissolution of the whole universe.
Translated: 7:6 Know that the full ghosts are derived from these two natures. (so) I am the source and place of the whole world.

Original: 7.7 There is nothing whatsoever higher than Me, O Arjuna. All this is strung on Me, as clusters of gems on a string.
Translated: 7 There is no better thing than me; there is no better thing than me; there is no better thing than me; there is no better thing than me; there is no better thing than me; there is no better thing than me; there is no better thing than me.

Original: 7.8 I am the sapidity in water, O Arjuna; I am the light in the moon and the sun; I am the syllable Om in all the Vedas, sound in ether and virility in men.
Translated: 7:8 I am water in water, I am light in the moon and the sun, I am worship in all the waters, and I am word in heaven, and mankind in men.

Original: 7.9 I am the sweet fragrance in the earth and the brilliance in the fire, the life in all beings, and I am the austerity in ascetics.
Translated: 7:9 I am the holy fool on earth, and I am bright in the fire; I am life in all the spirits, and I am thappiness in the thappiness.

Original: 7.10 Know Me, O Arjuna, as the eternal seed of all beings; I am the intelligence of the intelligent; the splendour of the splendid objects am I.
Translated: 7:10 O paths, know me the seed of all the spirits; I am the bright of the wise and the bright of the wise.

Original: 7.11 Of the strong, I am the strength devoid of desire and attachment, and in (all) beings, I am the desire unopposed to Dharma, O Arjuna.
Translated: I am the desire of the mighty and the power of the powerless, and in all spirits I am an unbelievers, i.e. a favorable work.

Original: 7.12 Whatever beings (and objects) that are pure, active and inert, know that they proceed from Me. They are in Me, yet I am not in them.
Translated: 7:12 Those who are seventh, righteous, and thamesic, you know all of them who have been born from me; but I am not in them, they are in me.

Original: 7.13 Deluded by these Natures (states or things) composed of the three alities of Nature all this world does not know Me as distinct from them and immutable.
Translated: 7:13 I do not know the unfair shape of the whole world (the people) that was overwhelmed by these feelings (the triangles) arising from these (the triangles).

Original: 7.14 Verily, this divine illusion of Mine, made up of the (three) alities (of Nature) is difficult to cross over; those who take refuge in Me alone, cross over this illusion.
Translated: 7:14 This divine triangle is my Maya a great disaster; but those who come in my shelter cross this Maya.

Original: 7.15 The evil-doers and the deluded who are the lowest of men do not seek Me; they whose knowledge is destroyed by illusion follow the ways of demons.
Translated: 7:15 The men who do evil, the mouthful, the wicked, do not eat me; by Maya whose knowledge has been all taken, they keep holding the sense of assure.

Original: 7.16 Four kinds of virtuous men worship Me, O Arjuna, and they are the distressed, the seekr of knowledge, the seekr of wealth and the wise, O lord of the Bharatas.
Translated: 7:16 O great Arjuna, those who do the best (success): art, curiosity, economists and wise are four kinds of people who eat me.

Original: 7.17 Of them the wise, ever steadfast and devoted to the One, excels (is the best); for I am exceedingly dear to the wise and he is dear to Me.
Translated: 7:17 And among them there is the wise one who is superior to me, the one who is solely devout, for I love the wise one, and he loves me.

Original: 7.18 Noble indeed are all these; but I deem the wise man as My very Self; for, steadfast in mind he is established in Me alone as the supreme goal.
Translated: 7:18 Those are all great, but the wise is my shape, so is not my; for the wise, the wise, is in me in a very good manner.

Original: 7.19 At the end of many births the wise man comes to Me, realising that all this is Vaasudeva (the innermost Self); such a great soul (Mahatma) is very hard to find.
Translated: 7:19 At the end of many births (in a special birth) I get the knowledge that ‘this is all the Vasudev’ the wise servant; such a great spirit is very rare.

Original: 7.20 Those whose wisdom has been rent away by this or that desire, go to other gods, following this or that rite, led by their own nature.
Translated: 7.20 With the desire of the special, whose knowledge is all taken, such men worship other gods inspired by their nature, following a specific rule.

Original: 7.21 Whatsoever form any devotee desires to worship with faith  that (same) faith of his I make firm and unflinching.
Translated: 7:21 Those who worship the form of whom he desires to worship with honour, I establish the honour to that God.

Original: 7.22 Endowed with that faith, he engages in the worship of that (form) and from it he obtains his desire, these being verily ordained by Me (alone).
Translated: 7:22 He worships the god with that honor, and receives from him the desirable foods which I have prescribed without doubt.

Original: 7.23 Verily the reward (fruit) that accrues to those men of small intelligence is finite. The worshippers of the gods go to them, but My devotees come to Me.
Translated: 7:23 But the fruit of those wise men is destroyed; the worshippers of the gods receive the gods, and my servants receive me.

Original: 7.24 The foolish think of Me, the Unmanifest, as having manifestation, knowing not My higher, immutable and most excellent nature.
Translated: 7:24 And the wicked men, without knowing the ultimate sense of my miserable (the best) unrighteousness, express me unrighteously.

Original: 7.25 I am not manifest to all (as I am) veiled by the Yoga-Maya. This deluded world does not know Me, the unborn and imperishable.
Translated: 7:25 I am not direct to all who are frequented by my Yogama; this wicked people (man) do not know the unborn of me, the immortal.

Original: 7.26 I know, O Arjuna, the beings of the past, the present and the future, but no one knows Me.
Translated: 7:26 O Arjuna, I know the ghosts that have passed in the east and in the present and in the future, but no man knows me.

Original: 7.27 By the delusion of the pairs of opposites arising from desire and aversion, O Bharata, all beings are subject to delusion at birth, O Parantapa.
Translated: 7:27 O Lord India! from the will and desire arising from the duct of the spiritual creation in the time of the creation, the consciousness is obtained.

Original: 7.28 But those men of virtuous deeds whose sins have come to an end, and who are freed from the delusion of the pairs of opposites, worship Me, steadfast in their vows.
Translated: 7:28 But those who do the sins of men who have been destroyed, those who are free from the twilight and strong men will serve me.

Original: 7.29 Those who strive for liberation from old age and death, taking refuge in Me, realise in full ï1thatï1 Brahman, the whole knowledge of the Self and all action.
Translated: 7:29 Those who are under Me and seek to get a little and a little freedom from death, men know that universe, the whole spirit and the whole karma.

Original: 7.30 Those who know Me with the Adhibhuta (pertaining to the elements), Adhidaiva (pertaining to the gods) and the Adhiyajna (pertaining to the sacrifice) know Me even at the time of death, steadfast in mind.
Translated: 7:30 Those men who know me, including the supreme and the supreme and the supreme, those who have the righteous men will know me in the end of the world.

Original: Swami Sivananda did not comment on this sloka
Translated: 8:1 And Arjuna said, O great man, what is that brahma, what is spirit, and what is karma, and what is said in the name of the greatest, and what is said in the name of the greatest?

Original: 8.2 Who and how is Adhiyajna here in this body, O destroyer of Madhu (Krishna)? And how at the time of death, art Thou to be known by the self-controlled?
Translated: 8:2 And who is the unknown here? and how is he in this body? and how are you known in the last time by men with holy mind?

Original: 8.3 The Blessed Lord said  Brahman is the Imperishable, the Supreme; Its essential nature is called Self-knowledge; the offering (to the gods) which causes existence and manifestation of beings and which also sustains them is called action.
Translated: 8:3 And the Lord said: The ultimate letter (undestructive) is the intelligence of Brahma; the nature (of its shape) is called spiritual; the spirit which generates the feelings of the ghosts is known by the name of the wise (knowledge, prophetic force) karma.

Original: 8.4 Adhibhuta (knowledge of the elements) pertains to My perishable Nature and the Purusha or the Soul is the Adhidaiva; I alone am the Adhiyajna here in this body, O best among the embodied (men).
Translated: 8:4 O greatest Arjuna among the bodies, the devastating thing is overwhelming, and the man is overwhelming; in this body I am only unknown.

Original: 8.5 And whosoever, leaving the body, goes forth remembering Me alone, at the time of death, he attains My Being: there is no doubt about this.
Translated: 8:5 And whoever gives up the body in the end of the world, remembering me, he receives my shape, there is no doubt in it.

Original: 8.6 Whosoever at the end leaves the body, thinking of any being, to that being only does he go, O son of Kunti (Arjuna), because of his constant thought of that being.
Translated: 8.6 O who! (this creature) in the end of life who reminds the body of any feeling, he always receives the same feeling as a result of the thought of that feeling.

Original: 8.7 Therefore at all times remember Me only and fight. With mind and intellect fixed (or absorbed) in Me, thou shalt doubtessly come to Me alone.
Translated: 8:7 So all of you remember me in the past, and fight with the mind that has been given to me, and with wisdom, you will surely receive me.

Original: 8.8 With the mind not moving towards any other thing, made steadfast by the method of habitual meditation, and constantly meditating, one goes to the Supreme Person, the Resplendent, O Arjuna.
Translated: 8.8 O parta, the ultimate divine man is obtained by the mind that does not go elsewhere with practice.

Original: 8.9 Whosoever meditates on the Omniscient, the Ancient, the Ruler (of the whole world), minuter than an atom, the supporter of all, of inconceivable form, effulgent like the sun and beyond the darkness of ignorance.
Translated: 8:9 He who reminds the man of all-know, old (old), all-in-law, even more subtle than subtil, all-in-law, in the form of light like the sun, and (unknown) the intelligence beyond the darkness.

Original: 8.10 At the time of death, with unshaken mind, endowed with devotio, by the power of Yoga, fixing the whole life-breath in the middle of the two eyrows, he reaches that resplendent Supreme Person.
Translated: 8:10 He (the righteous) at the end of the day establishes the soul from the yogable in the midst of the foolishness, and he (the righteous) receives the ultimate divine man with devotion from the unrighteous mind.

Original: 8.11 That which is declared Imperishable by those who know the Vedas, that which the self-controlled (ascetics or Sannyasins) and passion-free enter, that desiring which celibacy is practised  that goal I will declare to thee in brief.
Translated: 8:11 Those who know the wheat, whom the letters call; the wrathless and intense men in which they enter; whose will follow the universe, I will briefly tell you of that post.

Original: 8.12 Having closed all the gates, confined the mind in the heart and fixed the life-breath in the head, engaged in the practice of concentration.
Translated: 8:12 And all the doors were shut down, and the mind was established in the heart, and the soul was established in the mosquito.

Original: 8.13 Uttering the one-syllabled Om  the Brahman  and remembering Me, he who departs, leaving the body, attains to the Supreme Goal.
Translated: 8.13 The man who expresses a letter of Brahma and reminds himself of the body while reminding me, achieves the ultimate speed.

Original: 8.14 I am easily attainable by that ever-steadfast Yogi who constantly and daily remembers Me (for a long time), not thinking of anything else (with a single mind or one-pointed mind), O Partha (Arjuna).
Translated: 8:14 O Parath, who the unfair man remembers me, I am accessible to that unfair yogi, i.e. I am obtained.

Original:
8.15 Having attained Me these great souls do not again take birth (here) which is the place of pain 
and is non-eternal: they have reached the highest perfection (liberation).
Translated: 8:15 Those who have obtained the ultimate testimony will not receive me and will not obtain the resurrection of endless sorrow.

Original: 8.16 (All) the worlds including the world of Brahma are subject to return again, O Arjuna; but he who reaches Me, O son of Kunti, has no rirth.
Translated: 8:16 O Arjuna, all the people until the people of Brahma have a regaining nature; but, O Kantey, I would not be regained when I was received.

Original: 8.17 Those people who know the day of Brahma which is of a duration of a thousand Yugas (ages) and the night which is also of a thousand Yugas duration, they know day and night.
Translated: 8:17 Those who know the period of one day of Brahma G which is a thousand years and know a night of a thousand years are men who know the day and the night.

Original: 8.18 From the Unmanifested all the manifested (worlds) proceed at the coming of the 'day'; at the coming of the 'night' they dissolve verily into ï1thatï1 alone which is called the Unmanifested.
Translated: 8:18 And when the day rises, it comes from the unclean; and when the night comes, it becomes in the unclean.

Original: 8.19 This same multitude of beings, being born again and again, is dissolved, helplessly, O Arjuna (into the Unmanifested) at the coming of the night and comes forth at the coming of the day.
Translated: 8:19 This is the community of ghosts, which is resurrected and lies; this is the gospel, which is expressed upon the arrival of the night and upon the rise of the day.

Original: 8.20 But verily there exists, higher than this Unmanifested, another unmanifested Eternal, which is not destroyed when all beings are destroyed.
Translated: 8:20 But other than the unclean, the one who is ever unclean, would not be destroyed even if all the ghosts were destroyed.

Original: 8.21 What is called the Unmanifested and the Imperishable, That they say is the highest goal. They who reach It do not return (to this Samsara). That is My highest abode (place or state).
Translated: 8:21 Those who have been spoken with unfair letters are the ultimate speed, and those who are not returned (to the world) when they are obtained, they are my ultimate wrath.

Original: 8.22 That highest Purusha, O Arjuna, is attainable by unswerving devotion to Him alone within Whom all beings dwell and by Whom all this is pervaded.
Translated: 8:22 O Parath, whoever has all the spirits under him, and from whom it is entirely entirely entirely entirely entirely entirely entirely entirely.

Original: 8.23 Now I will tell thee, O chief of Bharatas, the times departing at which the Yogis will return or not return.
Translated: 8:23 O the best of all, in the day in which the bodies that have been abandoned (in the way) receive unrest and (or) recurrence, I will tell you the day (the way).

Original: 8.24 Fire, light daytime, the bright fortnight, the six months of the northern path of the sun (the northern solstice)  departing then (by these) men who know Brahman go to Brahman.
Translated: 8.24 Those who go by the path of the six masses of fire, light, day, shuklpart and Uttarayan, they get to the universe.

Original: 8.25 Attaining to the lunar light by smoke, night time, the dark fortnight also, the six months of the southern path of the sun (the southern solstice), the Yogi returns.
Translated: 8:25 And from the road of the six masses of the day, and the night, and the sun, and the moon, and the moon, and the moon, and the moon, and the moon, and the moon, and the moon.

Original: 8.26 The bright and the dark paths of the world are verily thought to be eternal; by the one (the bright path) a man goes not to return and by the other (the dark path) he returns.
Translated: 8:26 Those two kinds of worship and worship are considered to be worshipped; one (worship) is obtained by (worship) and another (worship) is repeated by (worship).

Original: 8.27 Knowing these paths, O Arjuna, no Yogi is deluded; therefore at all times be steadfast in Yoga.
Translated: 8:27 Those who know these two paths (from knowledge) would not have any yogi, so ye Arjuna, all of you shall be worthy in the day.

Original: 8.28 Whatever fruit of merit is declared (in the scriptures) to accrue from (the study of) the Vedas, (the performance of) sacrifices, (the practice of) austerities, and gifts  beyond all this goes the Yogi, having known this; and he attains to the Supreme Primeval (first or ancient) Abode.
Translated: 8:28 And the man of Yogi, knowing all this (the essence of both paths), breaches all that is said in the hedging, in the knowledge, in the thapping and in the donation, and obtains the ultimate place.

Original: 9.1 The Blessed Lord said  I shall now declare to thee who does not cavil, the greatest secret, the knowledge combined with experience (Self-realisation). Having known this thou shalt be free evil.
Translated: 9:1 And the Lord said, I will call this greatest knowledge for you unsuyo (without guilt of sight), including the knowledge of which you will be free from unhappy (world bonds).

Original: 9.2 This is the kingl science, the kingly secret, the supreme purifier, realisable by direct intuitional knowledge, according to righteousness, very easy to perform and imperishable.
Translated: 9:2 This knowledge is the king of science, and the king of secrets, and the holy, the best, the direct, the knowledgeable, and the godly, and it is simple and unfair to do.

Original: 9.3 Those who have no faith in this Dharma (knowledge of the Self), O Parantapa (Arjuna), return to the path of this world of death without attaining Me.
Translated: 9:3 But those who are not honoured in this religion do not receive me and live in the deadly world.

Original: 9.4 All this world is pervaded by Me in My unmanifest aspect; all beings exist in Me, but I do not dwell in them.
Translated: 9:4 This whole world is empty in the immaculate shape of Me; the spirit is in Me, but I am not in them.

Original: 9.5 Nor do beings exist in Me (in reality); behold My divine Yoga, supporting all beings, but not dwelling in them, is My Self, the efficient cause of beings.
Translated: 9:5 And the ghost is not in me; see my divine yoga that my spirit which holds ghosts and generates ghosts is not in those ghosts.

Original: 9.6 As the mighty wind, moving everywhere, rests always in the ether, even so, know thou that all beings rest in Me.
Translated: 9.6 As the great air that all speaks is always in heaven, so the whole ghost is in me, so you know.

Original: 9.7 All beings, O Arjuna, go into My Nature at the end of a Kalpa; I send them forth again at the beginning of (the next) Kalpa.
Translated: 9:7 O whoever, at the end of the imagination all the spirits receive my nature, and at the beginning of the imagination I re-create them.

Original: 9.8 Animating My Nature, I again and again send forth all this multitude of beings, helpless by the force of the Nature.
Translated: 9:8 And I will re-create the whole community of spirits, which has been overwhelmed by the spirit, by making the nature in my possession (i.e. by giving it awareness).

Original: 9.9 These acts do not bind Me, O Arjuna, sitting like one indifferent, unattached to those acts.
Translated: 9 And they do not binding me (permath) which is in those works without asset and like indifference; they do not binding me (permath) in those works.

Original: 9.10 Under Me as supervisor, Nature produces the moving and the unmoving; because of this, O Arjuna, the world revolves.
Translated: 9:10 O Counthey, because of my chair (i.e. in my chair) nature generates the characher; therefore it continues to rotates.

Original: 9.11 Fools disregard Me, clad in human form, not knowing My higher Being as the great Lord of (all) beings.
Translated: 9.11 The great God form of all ghosts, without knowing my ultimate spirit, humans humans humans humans humans humans humans humans humans humans humans humans humans.

Original: 9.12 Of vain hopes, of vain actions, of vain knowledge and senseless, they verily are possessed of the deceitful nature of demons and undivine beings.
9.13 But the great souls, O Arjuna, partaking of My divine nature, worship Me with a single mind (with the mind devoted to nothing else), knowing Me as the imperishable source of beings.
Translated: 9:13 But the great men of the divine nature devote me, knowing all the ghosts and unreasonably, with unrighteousness.

Original: 9.14 Always glorifying Me, striving,firm in vows, prostrating themselves before Me, they worship Me with devotion always steadfast.
Translated: 9:14 While constantly worshipping me, struggling, hardward men worshipping me, worshipping me with devotion.

Original: 9.15 Others also sacrificing with the wisdom-sacrifice worship Me, the All-faced, as one, as distinct, and as manifold.
Translated: 9:15 Those who worship me with unity by wise knowledge, Those who worship me with a separate spirit, Those who worship me in many ways in the form of the wrath.

Original: 9.16 I am the Kratu; I am the Yajna; I am the offering (food) to the manes; I am the medicinal herbs and all the plants; I am the Mantra; I am also the Ghee or the melted butter; I am the fire; I am the oblation.
Translated: 9:16 I am a lyric; I am a knowledge; I am a health and a medicine; I am a mole, I am a ghetto; I am a fire, and I am a heaven, i.e. I am a karma.

Original:
9.17 I am the father of this world, the mother, the dispenser of the fruits of actions and the 
grandfather; the (one) thing to be known, the purifier, the sacred monosyllable (Om), and also the Rik-, the Sama-and the Yajur-Vedas.
Translated: 9:17 I am the Father of this world, the Mother, the Metha, and the Father, I am the subject of the knowledge, and I am the Holy, the Ounkar, the Lungweed, the Samweed, and the Yuzurweed.

Original: 9.18 I am the goal, the supporter, the Lord, the witness, the abode, the shelter, the friend, the origin, the dissolution, the foundation, the treasure-house and the seed which is imperishable.
Translated: 9:18 I am the fast, the filler, the Lord, the witness, the residence, the shelter and the friend and the origin, the form and the place (the foundation), the discretion and the unrighteous cause.

Original: 9.19 (As the sun) I give heat; I withhold and send forth the rain; I am immortality and also death, existence and non-existence, O Arjuna.
Translated: 9:19 O Arjuna, I am thapting; I swear and empty rain; I am immortal and death and untruthful.

Original: 9.20 The knowers of the three Vedas, the drinkers of Soma, purified of all sins, worshipping Me by sacrifices, pray for the way to heaven; they reach the holy world of the Lord of the gods and enjoy in heavn the divine pleasures of the gods.
Translated: 9:20 The wise of the three wedds, the sunseting and the holy men of sins want to worship me through the wedds and to receive heaven; these men receive the fruit of their wedds and eat the wedds of the divine gods in heaven.

Original: 9.21 They, having enjoyed the vast heaven, enter the world of mortals when their merit is exhausted; thus abiding by the injunctions of the ï1threeï1 (Vedas) and desiring (objects of) desires, they attain to the state of going and returning.
Translated: 9:21 Thou shalt bear the great heavenly people, when they are purified, they receive the dead; thus the three wedds have been refuge of the karma, and the men who desire for the wedds receive the movement.

Original: 9.22 For those men who worship Me alone, thinking of no other, for those ever-united, I secure what is not already possessed and preserve what they already possess.
Translated: 9:22.With an exclusive spirit of thinking about me, the worshippers who worship me themselves, I carry the joint of those destroyed men.

Original: 9.23 Even those devotees who, endowed with faith, worship other gods, worship Me alone, O Arjuna, b the wrong method.
Translated: 9:23 O whoever honours those who worship other gods, they also worship me unprecedentedly.

Original: 9.24 (For) I alone am the enjoyer and also the Lord of all sacrifices; but they do not know Me in essence (in reality), and hence they fall (return to this mortal world).
Translated: 9:24 For I am the servant and master of all knowledge, but they know me; they do not know, so they fall, that is, they get the world.

Original: 9.25 The worshippers of the gods go to them; to the manes go the ancestor-worshippers; to the deities who preside over the elements go their worshippers; but My devotees come to Me.
Translated: 9.25 The worshippers of the gods receive the gods, the patriots go to the fathers, the ghosts who worship the ghosts receive, and the worshippers who worship me receive me.

Original: 9.26 Whoever offers Me with devotion a leaf, a flower, a fruit or a little water  that, so offered devotedly by the pure-minded, I accept.
Translated: 9:26 Any servant who offers for me letter, flowers, fruits, water, etc. with devotion, I accept the devotion of that servant of the pure mind (the letter of flowers).

Original: 9.27 Whatever thou doest, whatever thou eatest, whatever thou offerest in sacrifice, whatever thou givest, whatever thou practisest as austerity, O Arjuna, do it as an offering unto Me.
Translated: 9:27 O whoever you do, what you eat, what you need, what you donate, and what you repent, all that you offer me.

Original: 9.28 Thus shalt thou be freed from the bonds of actions yielding good and evil fruits; with the mind steadfast in the Yoga of renunciation, and liberated, thou shalt come unto Me.
Translated: 9:28 Thus you will be free from the works of blessing, and you will be free from the works of blessing, and you will be received by me.

Original: 9.29 The same am I to all beings; to Me there is none hateful or dear; but those who worship Me with devotion are in Me and I am also in them.
Translated: 9:29 I am equal among all spirits; no one is unpleasant to me nor loved to me; but those who devote me are in me and I am in them.

Original: 9.30 Even if the most sinful worships Me, with devotion to none else, he too should indeed by regarded as righteous for he has rightly resolved.
Translated: 9:30 If even a very evil man worshipps me in sinfulness as a servant of me, then he is worthy of righteousness, for he is indeed righteous.

Original: 9.31 Soon he becomes righteous and attains to eternal peace; O Arjuna, proclaim thou for certain that My devotee never perishes.
Translated: 9:31 He will soon become a righteous man, and will obtain eternal peace; for you know the truth that my servant will never be destroyed.

Original: 9.32 For, taking refuge in Me, they also who, O Arjuna, may be of a sinful birth  women, Vaisyas as well as Sudras  attain the Supreme Goal.
Translated: 9:32 O paths, women, wassals, and shudras, those who are sinners, they are also dependent on Me (My shelter) and obtain the ultimate speed.

Original: 9.33 How much more (easily) then the hold Brahmins and devoted royal saints (attain the goal); having come to this impermanent and unhappy world, do thou worship Me.
Translated: 9:33 Then what do you say, ‘Punishable brahman and the righteous righteous righteous righteous righteous righteous righteous?

Original: 9.34 Fix thy mind on Me; by devoted to Me; sacrifice unto Me; bow down to Me; having thus united thy whole self to Me, taking Me as the supreme goal, thou shalt come unto Me.
Translated: 9:34 Be stable in me; be my servants and my worshippers; greet me; thus you will receive me by bringing the Spirit to me, being the worshippers.

Original: 10.1 The Blessed Lord said  Again, O mighty-armed Arjuna, listen to my supreme word which I will declare to thee who who art beloved, for thy welfare.
Translated: 10:1 And the Lord said, O great, again listen to my last words, which I will say with the will of interest to the one who loves you.

Original: 10.2 Neither the hosts of the gods nor the great sages know My origin; for in every way I am the source of all the gods and the great sages.
Translated: 10:2 My creation is not known by the gods, nor by the worshippers; for I am the adicator of all kinds of gods and worshippers.

Original: 10.3 He who knows Me as unborn and beginningless, as the great Lord of the worlds, he, among mortals, is undeluded and he is liberated from all sins.
Translated: 10:3 Whoever knows me as the great God of Aznma, Anadi and the peoples, in the righteous men such an unconscious man becomes free from all sins.

Original: 10.4 Intellect, wisdom, non-delusion, forgiveness, truth, self-restraint, calmness, happiness, pain, existence or birth, non-existence or death, fear and also fearlessness.
Translated: 10.4 Wisdom, wisdom, lack of moh, forgiveness, truth, dam, sham, pleasure, sadness, birth and death, fear and shame.

Original: 10.5 Non-injury, eanimity, contentment, austerity, beneficence, fame, ill-fame  (these) different kinds of alities of beings arise from Me alone.
Translated: 10.5. non-violence, equality, satisfaction, tap, donation, and failure such these beings are manifested by me.

Original: 10.6 The seven great sages, the ancient four and also the Manus, possessed of powers like Me (on account of their minds being fixed on Me), were born of (My) mind; from them are these creatures born in this world.
Translated: 10:6 Seven Maharishans, four of the ancient days, and [thirteen] men, these are from my determination that has my influence, whose people are this nation in the world.

Original: 10.7 He who in truth knows these manifold manifestations of My Being and (this) Yoga-power of Mine becomes established in the unshakable Yoga; there is no doubt about it.

Translated: 11:38 You are ididev and purane men; you are the ultimate shelter of this world, the knowledgeable, the knowledgeable, and the ultimate righteous.

Translated: 11:43 You are the Father of this Character World, the worshiping and the best master.O God of infinite influence!There is no one like you among the three people, then how will it be better than you?

Original: 11.45 I am delighted, having seen what has never been seen before; and yet my mind is distressed with fear. Show me that (previous) form only, O God; have mercy, O God of gods, O Abode of the universe.
Translated: 11:45 I am glad to see this invisible shape of you, and my mind is overwhelmed by fear, so God, you show me that time before.

Translated: 11:47 O Arjuna, I have revealed to you, by the influence of my strength, my ultimate strength, all things, and the eternal world, which no one before you has seen.

Translated: 11:48 O Corinthians, by anyone else in this people, except you, I can be seen in this form, neither by weddings nor by knowledge, neither by gifts nor by (religious) actions, nor by anger.
