Original: 11.50 Sanjaya said  Having thus spoken to Arjuna, Krishna again showed His own form and the great Soul (Krishna), assuming His gentle form, consoled him (Arjuna) who was terrified.
Translated: 11:50 Sanjay said, God said to Arjuna this way, reaffirming his (previous) shape, and then, so much, Mahatma Sriकृष्ण persuaded this frightening Arjuna.

Original: 11.51 Arjuna said  Having seen this Thy gentle human form, O Krishna, now I am composed and am restored to my own nature.
Translated: 11:51 Arjuna said, "Generate, now I have been calmed and achieved my nature by seeing this kind human shape of you.

Original: 11.52 The Blessed Lord said  Very hard indeed it is to see this form of Mine which thou hast seen. Even the gods are ever longing to behold it.
Translated: He said, “It is very rare for me to see this form, which you have seen; the gods are also always willing to see this form.

Original: 11.53 Neither by the Vedas nor by austerity, nor by gift, nor by sacrifice can I be seen in this form as thou hast seen Me (so easily).
Translated: 11:53 And I can not be seen by wedds, nor by compassion, nor by gifts, nor by knowledge, as you have seen me.

Original: 11.54 But by single-minded devotion can I, of this Form, be known and seen in reality and also entered into, O Arjuna.
Translated: 11:54 But, O Arjuna, by the sole devotion, I am also capable of ‘knowing’, ‘seeing’ and ‘input’ (to be obtained in one sense).

Original: 11.55 He who does all actions for Me, who looks upon Me as the Supreme, who is devoted to Me, who is free from attachment, who bears enmity towards no creature, he comes to Me, O Arjuna.
Translated: 11:55 O Pandou, the man who will only work for me, and considers me as the ultimate goal, who is my servant and preserved, who is unbearable to the spirit, he receives me.

Original: 12.1 Arjuna said  Those devotees who, ever steadfast, thus worship Thee and those also who worship the imperishable and the unmanifested  which of them are better versed in Yoga?
Translated: 12:1 Arjuna said, "Who is the best of those who worship you in this way and whoever worship the worshipers and the worshipers of the wicked?"

Original: 12.2 The Blessed Lord said  Those who, fixing their mind on Me, worship Me, ever steadfast and endowed with supreme faith, are the best in Yoga in My opinion.
Translated: 12:2 And the Lord said, “Those who have concentrated their minds in me, who worship me with great honour, are, by my will, the best, that is, the best.”

Original: Swami Sivananda did not comment on this sloka
Translated: Swami Tejomayananda did not comment on this sloka

Original: 12.4 Having restrained all the senses, even-minded everywhere, intent on the welfare of all beings  verily they also come unto Me.
Translated: 12.4 By regulating the intellectual community in the same way, all the possessed, in the interest of the spirit, the worshippers receive me.

Original: 12.5 Greater is their trouble whose minds are set on the unmanifested; for the goal; the unmanifested, is very hard for the embodied to reach.
Translated: 12:5 But the men with the minds in those unrighteous are more distressed, because the fastness of the unrighteous is hardly achieved by the bodies.

Original: 12.6 But to those who worship Me, renouncing all actions in Me, regarding Me as the supreme gaol, meditating on Me with single-minded Yoga.
Translated: 12:6 But those who worship me, considering me as the ultimate goal, by offering me all the works, they only take care of me by unuse.

Original: 12.7 To those whose minds are set on Me, O Arjuna, verily I become ere long the saviour out of the ocean of Samsara.
Translated: 12:7 O Parth, whose mind is stable in me, of such servants I will soon be saved from the sea of the world in death.

Original: 12.8 Fix thy mind in Me only, thy intellect in Me, (then) thou shalt no doubt live in Me alone hereafter.
Translated: 12:8 Stay your mind and wisdom in me, so you will dwell in me, there is no doubt in it.

Original: 12.9 If thou art unable to fix thy mind steadily on Me, then by the Yoga of constant practice do thou seek to reach Me, O Arjuna.
Translated: 12:9 If you are unable to establish your mind in me, then by practice you want to get me (i.e. try).

Original: 12.10 If thou art unable to practise even this Abhyasa Yoga, be thou intent on doing actions for My sake; even by doing actions for My sake, thou shalt attain perfection.
Translated: 12:10 If you are also unable to practice, then be a martyr; thus you will obtain proof even when you do the works for me.

Original: 12.11 If thou art unable to do even this, then, resorting to union with Me, renounce the fruits of all actions with the self controlled.
Translated: 12:11 And if you are also unable to do this, then with self-consciousness, taking the shelter of my achievement, give up the fruit of all the works.

Original: 12.12 Better indeed is knowledge than practice; than knowledge meditation is better; than meditation the renunciation of the fruits of actions: peace immediately follows renunciation.
Translated: 12.12 Knowledge is better than practice; Knowledge is better than attention, and the best of care is abandonment; immediately there is peace.

Original: 12.13 He who hates no creature, who is friendly and compassionate to all, who is free from attachment and egoism, balanced in pleasure and pain, and forgiving.
Translated: 12:13 to the ghost who is wicked, and everyone's friend and compassionate; who is free of compassion and selfishness, equal and forgiven in pleasure and sadness.

Original: 12.14 Ever content, steady in meditation, self-controlled, possessed of firm conviction, with the mind and intellect dedicated to Me, he, My devtoee, is dear to Me.
Translated: 12:14 Whoever is the Sitatathma, the persistent Yogi, eternally satisfied, whoever has sacrificed his mind and wisdom in me, whoever is such my servant, he is my beloved.

Original: 12.15 He by whom the world is not agitated and who cannot be agitated by the world, and who is freed from joy, anger, fear and anxiety  he is dear to Me.
Translated: 12:15 Those with whom no people (i.e. beings, persons) can obtain awakening, and whoever himself does not experience awakening from any person, and whoever is free of fear and awakening, the servant is my beloved.

Original: 12.16 He who is free from wants, pure, expert, unconcerned, and free from pain, renouncing all undertakings or commencements  he who is (thus) devoted to Me, is dear to Me.
Translated: 12:16 Whoever is my servant without expectation, pure, purity, indifference, miserable, and the dishonor of all things, he is my beloved.

Original: 12.17 He who neither rejoices, nor hates, nor grieves, nor desires, renouncing good and evil, and who is full of devotion, is dear to Me.
Translated: 12:17 Whoever does not rejoice nor deceives; whoever does not sorrow nor desire; and whoever gives up the good and the unpleasant, he is the godly man who loves me.

Original: Swami Sivananda did not comment on this sloka
Translated: Swami Tejomayananda did not comment on this sloka

Original: 12.19 He to whom censure and praise are eal, who is silent, content with anything, homeless, of a steady mind, and full of devotion  that man is dear to Me.
Translated: 12:19 Whoever is equal to condemnation and praise, whoever is silent, whoever is satisfied with a little thing, whoever is unjust, he is the devout man of stable wisdom, I love.

Original: 12.20 They verily who follow this immortal Dharma (law or doctrine) as described above, endowed with faith, regarding Me as their supreme goal, they, the devotees, are exceedingly dear to Me.
Translated: 12.20 Those who are worshippers and who will understand me as the ultimate goal and follow this one-time religious immortal, i.e. religious life, are very loved to me.

Original: 13.1 Arjuna said  I wish to learn about Nature (matter) and the Spirit (soul), the field and the knower of the field, knowledge and that which ought to be known, O Kesava.
Translated: 13:1 And Arjuna said, O Keshov, I want to know nature and man, land and land, and knowledge and knowledge.

Original: 13.2 The Blessed Lord said  This body, O Arjuna, is called the field; he who knows it is called the knower of the field, by those who know of them.
Translated: 13:2 And the Lord said, O Counthey, this is called the body area, and whoever knows it, is called the theologian people, the regionologists.

Original: 13.3 Do thou also know Me as the knower of the field in all fields, O Arjuna. Knowledge of both the field and the knower of the field is considered by Me to be ï1the ï1 knowledge.
Translated: 13:3 O India, you know me in all the regions; the knowledge of the region and the knowledge of the region is the knowledge, so is not me.

Original: 13.4 What the field is and of what nature, what are its modifications and whence it is and also who He is and what His powers are  hear all that from Me in brief.
Translated: 13:4 Therefore, the area which is and which is, and which has disturbances, and which has happened, and which is, and which has effect, hear me in short.

Original: 13.5 Sages have sung in many ways, in various distinctive chants and also in the suggestive words indicative of the Absolute, full of reasoning and decisive.
Translated: 13.5 (with regard to the territory-regionist) has been singed in many ways by the ऋषi in various and varied signs, and has been determined in the same way by the positions of the advised Brahmsour (i.e. by the indicating words of the Brahms) (as is said).

Original: 13.6 The great elements, egoism, intellect, and also the Unmanifested Nature, the ten senses and one (mind), and the five objects of the senses.
Translated: Punch great spirit, ego, wisdom, unfair (natural), ten senses, one mind, five subjects of senses.

Original: 13.7 Desire, hatred, pleasure, pain, the aggregate (the body), intelligence, fortitude  the field has thus been briefly described with its modifications.
Translated: The desire, the desire, the pleasure, the sadness, the trauma (stuldeh), the consciousness (the conscious instinct of evolution) and the patience – thus this area is stated in short, including disturbances.

Original: 13.8 Humility, unpretentiousness, non-injury, forgiveness, uprightness, service of the teacher, purity, steadfastness, self-control.
Translated: 13.8 Immanity, immanity, non-violence, forgiveness, harshness, service, purity, stability and self-conciliation.

Original: 13.9 Indifference to the objects of the senses and also absence of egoism; perception of (or reflection on) the evil in birth, death, old age, sickness and pain.
Translated: 13.9 Varagity to the subject of the human beings, lack of ego, birth, death, aging, praise and misconduct in philosophy.

Original: 13.10 Non-attachment, non-identification of the Self with son, wife, home and the rest, and constant even-mindedness on the attainment of the desirable and the undesirable.
Translated: 13:10 In mankind and son, and wife, and household, and so on, and on, and on, and on, and on, and on, and on, and on.

Original: 13.11 Unswerving devotion unto Me by the Yoga of non-separation, resort to solitary places, distaste for the society of men.
Translated: 13.11 In me by abuse unacceptable devotion; the nature of living in a solitary place and the interest in the community of (non-cultural) peoples.

Original: 13.12 Constancy in Self-knowledge, perception of the end of true knowledge  this is declared to be knowledge, and what is opposed to it is ignorance.
Translated: 13.12 In spiritual science, intelligence, i.e. stability, and theology means the philosophy of God, all this is called wisdom, and what is contrary to it is ignorance.

Original: 13.13 I will declare that which has to be known, knowing which one attains to immortality, the beginningless supreme Brahman, called neither being nor non-being.
Translated: 13:13 I will clarify the knowledgeable thing which by knowing man achieves immortality; it is knowledgeable - anad, the ultimate universe, which cannot be called truth and truth.

Original: 13.14 With hands and feet everywhere, with eyes, heads and mouths everywhere, with ears everywhere, He exists in the worlds enveloping all.
Translated: 13:14 He is hand-foot on all sides, and eye on all sides, head and head, and hearing on all sides; he is all in the world, and he is all in the world.

Original: 13.15 Shining by the functions of all the senses, yet without the senses; unattached, yet supporting all; devoid of alities, yet their experiencer.
Translated: 13:15 He shall be revealed by the qualities of all men, but he shall be free of all men; he shall feed all men, and he shall be the servant of the qualities, even though he is free of person and without qualities.

Original: 13.16 Without and within (all) beings the unmoving and also the moving; because of Its subtlety, unknowable; and near and far away is That.
Translated: 13:16 He is in the midst of the spirit alone; he is varied and unknown; he is unknown from being subtle; he is also far away and very close.

Original: 13.17 And undivided, yet It exists as if divided in beings; It is to be known as the supporter of being; It devours and It generates.
Translated: 13:17 And he is inseparable, yet he is like the divided in the ghosts; he is the wise universe, the filler of the ghost, the promoter and the creator.

Original: 13.18 That, the Light of all lights, is said to be beyond darkness: knowledge, the knowable and the goal of knowledge, seated in the hearts of all.
Translated: 13:18 And the light is called beyond the light and the darkness; and he is knowledgeable by knowledge, and knowledgeable by knowledge; and he is in the hearts of all.

Original: 13.19 Thus the field, as well as knowledge and the knowable have been briefly stated. My devotee, knowing this, enters into My Being.
Translated: 13:19 So (by me) the field, the knowledge and the knowledge are shortened: it is said, knowing it by wisdom, my servant receives my shape.

Original: 13.20 Know thou that Nature (matter) and the Spirit are both beginningless; and know also that all modifications and alities are born of Nature.
Translated: 13:20 You know both nature and men, and you also know that all disorders and qualities are derived from nature.

Original: 13.21 In the production of the effect and the cause, Nature (matter) is said to be the cause; in the experience of pleasure and pain, the soul is said to be the cause.
Translated: 13.21 Nature is called for the creation of work and cause, and man is called for the purity of Sukh-du-kh.

Original: 13.22 The soul seated in Nature experiences the alities born of Nature; attachment to the alities is the cause of its birth in good and evil wombs.
Translated: 13.22 The man in nature enjoys the qualities arising from nature; the same of these qualities is the reason for the birth in the happy and unhappy vagina of this man (life).

Original: 13.23 The Supreme Soul in this body is also called the spectator, the permitter, the supporter, the enjoyer, the great Lord and the Supreme Self.
Translated: 13:23 The ultimate man in this body is called subtrahts, permits, worshippers, worshippers, gods and gods.

Original: 13.24 He who thus knows the Spirit and Matter together with the alities, in whatever condition he may be, he is not born again.
Translated: 13:24 Thus, the man who knows the nature, including man and qualities, does not resurrect in all forms of life.

Original: 13.25 Some by meditation behold the Self in the self by the self, others by the Yoga of knowledge, and still others by the Yoga of action.
Translated: 13:25 A man from the practice of meditation sees the spirit in the spirit (heart) through the spirit (clean intelligence); others through statistical yoga and by a searching work (see the spirit).

Original: 13.26 Others also, not knowing thus, worship, having heard of It from others; they, too, cross beyond death, regarding what they have heard as the Supreme refuge.
Translated: 13:26 But those who do not know this, but listen to others and worship, and those who hear, and those who hear, and those who hear, and those who hear, and those who hear, and those who hear, and those who hear, and those who hear, and those who hear, and those who hear.

Original: 13.27 Wherever a being is born, whether unmoving or moving, know thou, O best of the Bharatas (Arjuna), that it is from the union between the field and its knower.
Translated: 13:27 O the best of all, whoever creates a permanent forest (chracher) object, you all know that you have generated from the coincidence of the land and the landlord.

Original: 13.28 He sees, who sees the Supreme Lord, existing eally in all beings, the unperishing within the perishing.
Translated: 13:28 The man who sees the unrighteous God in all the devastating ghosts, he sees (in truth).

Original: 13.29 Because he who sees the same Lord eally dwelling everywhere does not destroy the Self by the self; he goes to the highest goal.
Translated: 13:29 Indeed, the man does not destroy the Spirit (self) by the Spirit (self) equal to God, which is allly equal to his spirit, by which he achieves the ultimate speed.

Original: 13.30 He sees, who sees that all actions are performed by Nature alone and that the Self is actionless.
Translated: 13:30 Whoever sees all the works of all things, which are done by nature, and sees the Spirit, he sees (in truth).

Original: 13.31 When a man sees the whole variety of beings as resting in the One, and spreading forth from That alone, he then becomes Brahman.
Translated: 13:31 This man, when he sees the separate feelings of ghosts located in one (permathy) and knows that it has expanded from that (permathy), then he receives the universe.

Original: 13.32 Being without beginning and being devoid of (any) alities, the Supreme Self, imperishable, though dwelling in the body, O Arjuna, neither acts nor is tainted.
Translated: 13:32 This God is unfair from being unclean and unclean; even if it is in the body, it does not (work) nor (from the fruits) it is unclean.

Original: 13.33 As the all-pervading ether is not tainted, because of its subtlety, so the Self seated everywhere in the body is not tainted.
Translated: 13:33 As the whole heavens were not filled because of their subtility, so the whole body was not filled by the spirit.

Original:
13.34 Just as the one sun illumines the whole world, so also the Lord of the field (Supreme Self) 
illumines the whole field, O Arjuna.
Translated: Oh India! as the same sun reveals this whole people, the same region (regional) reveals the whole area.

Original: 13.35 They who, by the eye of knowledge, perceive the distinction between the field and its knower and also the liberation from the Nature of being, go to the Supreme.
Translated: 13.35 Thus, those who know the difference between the region and the region by the knowledge, and the salvation by the disorders of nature, they obtain the ultimate universe.

Original: 14.1 The Blessed Lord said  I will again declare (to thee) that supreme knowledge, the best of all knowledge, having known which all the sages have gone to the supreme perfection after this life.
Translated: 14:1 And the LORD said, I will reiterate the best of all knowledge, the best of all knowledge, whom all the Munians know and have gone from this (people) and obtained the best proof.

Original: 14.2 They who, having taken refuge in this knowledge, have attained to unity with Me, are neither born at the time of creation nor are they disturbed at the time of dissolution.
Translated: 14.2 The men who have received my shape with the shelter of this knowledge shall not be born in the beginning of creation, nor shall they be troubled in the early days.

Original: 14.3 My womb is the great Brahma; in that I place the germ; thence, O Arjuna, is the birth of all beings.
Translated: 14:3 O India, my great universe nature is the vagina of (the spirits), in which I breathe; it is the origin of all the spirits.

Original: 14.4 Whatever forms are produced, O Arjuna, in any womb whatsoever, the great Brahma is their womb and I am the seed-giving father.
Translated: 14:4 O Counthey, all the statues (the bodies) which are born in all the joints, all the joints (the joints) that are pregnant are Mahadbraham, and I am the Father who establishes the seed.

Original: 14.5 Purity, passion and inertia  these alities, O Arjuna, born of Nature, bind fast in the body, the embodied, the indestructible.
Translated: 14:5 O great, truth, rz and tham these three qualities arising from nature bind the soul with the body.

Original: 14.6 Of these, Sattva, which from its stainlessness is luminous and healthy, binds by attachment to happiness and by attachment to knowledge, O sinless one.
Translated: 14:6 O disgrace Arjuna, in these [three] [three] [three] [three] [three] [three] [three] [three] [three] [three] [three] [three] [three] [three] [three] [three] [three] [three] [three] [three] [three] [three] [three] [three] [three] [three] [three] [three] [three] [three] [three] [three] [three] [three] [three] [three] [three] [three] [three] [three] [three]

Original: 14.7 Know thou Rajas to be of the nature of passion, the source of thirst (for sensual enjoyment) and attachment; it binds fast, O Arjuna, the embodied one by attachment to action.
Translated: 14:7 O whoever, know the righteous as a rage, from which the creation and the asset are generated; it binds the soul with the asset of the works.

Original: 14.8 But know thou Tamas to be born of ignorance, deluding all embodied beings; it binds fast, O Arjuna, by heedlessness, indolence and sleep.
Translated: 14:8 And O India, know the Tamogun, which is born from ignorance; who will envy all the bodies; he binds the living by praise, lazy and unrighteous.

Original: 14.9 Sattva attaches to happiness, Rajas to action, O Arjuna, while Tamas verily shrouding knowledge attaches to heedlessness.
Translated: 14.9 O India, the hundreds of thousands of thousands of thousands of thousands of thousands of thousands of thousands of thousands of thousands of thousands of thousands of thousands of thousands of thousands of thousands of thousands of thousands of thousands.

Original: 14.10 Now Sattva arises (prevails), O Arjuna, having overpowered Rajas and Tamas; nor Rajas, having overpowered Sattva and Tamas; and now Tamas, having overpowered Sattva and Rajas.
Translated: 14:10 O India, when the rage and the thumb are overwhelmed and the rage and the thumb are overwhelmed, when the rage and the thumb are overwhelmed and the thumb are overwhelmed and the thumb are overwhelmed.

Original: 14.11 When through every gate (sense) in this body, the wisdom-light shines, then it may be known that Sattva is predominant.
Translated: 14:11 When the doors of this flesh, i.e. all men, are lighted in the form of knowledge, then know the richness.

Original: 14.12 Greed, activity, the undertaking of actions, restlessness, longing  these arise when Rajas is predominant, O Arjuna.
Translated: 14:12 And when the righteous righteous righteous righteous righteous righteous righteous righteous righteous righteous righteous righteous righteous righteous

Original: 14.13 Darkness, inertness, heedlessness and delusion  these arise when Tamas is predominant, O Arjuna.
Translated: 14:13 O Corinthians, when the Tamogun is rich, unpricedness, unpricedness, praise and moh all these are generated.

Original: 14.14 If the embodied one meets with death when Sattva is predominant, then he attains to the spotless worlds of the knowers of the Highest.
Translated: 14:14 When this creature gets death in the rise of the heavens, then it gets the immaculate of those who do the best, that is, the people of heaven.

Original: 14.15 Meeting death in Rajas, he is born among those who are attached to action; and dying in Tamas, he is born in the womb of the senseless.
Translated: 14:15 And when he dies, he shall be born in the people of work, and when he dies, he shall be born in the people of work, and when he dies, he shall be born in the people of work.

Original: 14.16 The fruit of good action, they say, is Sattvic and pure, verily the fruit of Rajas is pain, and ignorance is the fruit of Tamas.
Translated: 14:16 The fruit of good karma is said to be seventh and immaculate; the fruit of Rajogun is sad; and the fruit of Tamogun is ignorance.

Original: 14.17 From Sattva arises knowledge, and greed from Rajas; heedlessness and delusion arise from Tamas, and also ignorance.
Translated: 14.17 Knowledge is generated from the Seventh; from the Rajogun, the Lob and the Tamogun, the Pramade, the Mooh and the Ignorance are generated.

Original: 14.18 Those who are seated in Sattva go upwards; the Rajasic dwell in the middle; and the Tamasic, abiding in the function of the lowest Guna, go downwards.
Translated: 14:18 The men in the Seventh Gone go high (to the people); the men in the midst (the men in the people) live, and the people in the extreme tendens of the Tamogun get unfolded.

Original: 14.19 When the seer beholds no agent other than the Gunas and knows That which is higher than they, he attains to My Being.
Translated: 14:19 When the righteous man does not see any other person but the three qualities, that is, does not understand, and knows my element beyond the three qualities, then he receives my shape.

Original: 14.20 The embodied one having crossed beyond these three Gunas out of which the body is evolved, is freed from birth, death, decay and pain, and attains to immortality.
Translated: 14.20 This body, due to the origin of the man’s body, is passed by the three qualities and achieves the immortality free from birth, death, shortness and suffering.

Original: 14.21 Arjuna said  What are the marks of him who has transcended the three alities, O Lord? What is his conduct and how does he go beyond these three alities?
Translated: 14:21 And Arjuna said, O Lord, what is the characteristic of a man who has passed through these three qualities, what kind of behavior he is, and what measure he has passed through these three qualities?

Original: 14.22 The Blessed Lord said  When light, activity and delusion are present, he hates them not, nor does he long for them when they are absent.
Translated: 14:22 And the Lord said, "O Pandwa! (the man of knowledge) does not sweep them even when the light, the tendency, and the moh tends to be, and does not sweep them when it is sweep.

Original: 14.23 He who, seated like one unconcerned, is not moved by the alities, and who, knowing that the alities are active, is self-centred and moves not.
Translated: 14.23 Whoever has the same assence as indifference cannot be distorted by qualities and “bear the same behaviour” is so aware and cannot be distorted by that situation.

Original: 14.24 Who is the same in pleasure and pain, who dwells in the Self, to whom a clod of earth, stone and gold are alike, who is the same to the dear and the unfriendly, who is firm, and to whom censure and praise are as one.
Translated: 14:24 Whoever is healthy (in shape), is equal in pleasure, and holds compassion in soil, stone, and gold; such a wicked man is equal to loved and unpleasant, and to denial and self-presentation.

Original: 14.25 Who is the same in honour and dishonour, the same to friend and foe, abandoning all undertakings  he is said to have transcended the alities.
Translated: 14:25 Whoever is equal in honour and insult; whoever is equal in favour of enemy and friend, such a servaramb abandonment man is called multiplied.

Original: 14.26 And he who serves Me with unswerving devotion, he, crossing beyond the alities, is fit for becoming Brahman.
Translated: 14.26 Whoever man worship my service through unacceptable devotion, he becomes eligible to become universe by the past of these three qualities.

Original: 14.27 For I am the abode of Brahman, the immortal and the immutable, of everlasting Dharma and of absolute bliss.
Translated: 14:27 For I am the reputation of immortal, unfair, brahm, eternal religion, and anecanical, i.e. parmatic pleasure.

Original: 15.1 The Blessed Lord said  They (the wise) speak of the indestructible peepul tree having its root above and branches below, whose leaves are the metres or hymns: he who knows it is a knower of the Vedas.
Translated: 15:1 And the Lord said, (the man who knows the tree of this world) they say: Urdhumul and Muf: Shaka's Ashvath and Mufy; whose horns are Shand, i.e. Wade, that (the tree of the world) who knows, he is Wade.

Original: 15.2 Below and above spread its branches, nourished by the Gunas; sense-objects are its buds; and below, in the world of men, stretch forth the roots, originating action.
Translated: 15:2 The branches of that tree have been rich in qualities and are spread down and up; the subjects are its grains; the other roots of it that follow the works in the people are spread down.

Original: 15.3 Its form is not perceived here as such, neither its end nor its origin, nor its foundation nor resting place: having cut asunder this firmly rooted peepul tree with the strong axe of non-attachment.
Translated: 15.3 The shape of this (the world tree) is not available here, as it is said, because it has neither the beginning nor the end nor the reputation.

Original: 15.4 Then That goal should be sought for, whither having gone none returns again. I seek refuge in that Primeval Purusha Whence streamed forth the ancient activity or energy.
Translated: 15.4 (Taduprat) must explore the position to which achieved men do not return to the re-world. ”I am the refuge of that first man, from which this ancient tendency has been spread.”

Original: 15.5 Free from pride and delusion, victorious over the evil of attachment, dwelling constantly in the Self, their desires having completely turned away, freed from the pairs of opposites known as pleasure and pain, the undeluded reach the eternal goal.
Translated: 15:5 Those whose honour and moh have been revived, those who have won the compassion, those who are in the spirit whose desires have been revived, and those who have been exempt from the duties called Sukh-du-kh, such unhumous wise men receive that unhumous position.

Original: 15.6 Neither doth the sun illumine there nor the moon, nor the fire; having gone thither they return not; that is My supreme abode.
Translated: 15:6 It cannot be lighted by the sun, nor by the moon, nor by the fire, which man does not return, it is my ultimate shadow.

Original: 15.7 An eternal portion of Myself having become a living soul in the world of life, draws to (itself) the (five) senses with the mind for the sixth, abiding in Nature.
Translated: 15:7 In this living people, I have made a whole part of the living being, which is in nature (at the time of the testimony) that draws five people and the mind to his side, that is, that is, that he gathers them.

Original: 15.8 When the Lord (as the individual soul) obtains a body and when He leaves it, He takes these and goes (with them) as the wind takes the scents from their seats (flowers, etc.).
Translated: 15:8 And when God (the living of God) comes out (from one body), he takes these (minds and minds) and takes them into another body, as it takes the air from the shelter (from the fruit) to the shelter.

Original: 15.9 Presiding over the ear, the eye, touch, taste and smell, as well as the mind, it enjoys the objects of the senses.
Translated: 15:9 (This creature) hears the hears, the hears, the hears, the hears, the hears, the hears, the hears, the hears, the hears, the hears, the hears, the hears, the hears, the hears, the hears, the hears, and the hears.

Original: 15.10 The deluded do not see Him Who departs, stays and enjoys; but they who possess the eye of knowledge behold Him.
Translated: 15:10 Those who give up the body, who are in it, or who eat, do not see the Spirit, which is co-ordinated with the qualities; but those who know, do not see it.

Original: 15.11 The Yogins striving (for perfection) behold Him dwelling in the Self; but, the unrefined and unintelligent, even though striving, see Him not.
Translated: 15:11 Those who try and see the Spirit in their hearts, when those who have the unclean end, and those who are unconscious, they do not see it, even if they try.

Original: 15.12 That light which residing in the sun illumines the whole world, that which is in the moon and in the fire  know that light to be Mine.
Translated: 15:12 Those who are in the bright sun and light the whole world, and those who are in the bright moon and in the fire, you know me.

Original: 15.13 Permeating the earth I support all beings by (My) energy; and having become the watery moon I nourish all herbs.
Translated: 15:13 I am entering the earth, holding the ghost from my oze, and becoming a moon as a resurrection, feeding all the medications, i.e. the plants.

Original: 15.14 Having become the fire Vaisvanara, I abide in the body of living beings and, associated with the Prana and the Apana, digest the fourfold food.
Translated: 15:14 I am the one who is in the body of all beings, and I am the one who is in the body of all beings, and I am the one who is in the body of all beings, and I am the one who is in the body of all beings.

Original: 15.15 And I am seated in the hearts of all; from Me are memory and knowledge, as well as their absence. I am verily That which has to be known by all the Vedas; I am indeed the author of the Vedanta and the knower of the Vedas am I.
Translated: 15:15 And I am in the hearts of all creatures, and I am the memory, the knowledge, and the disappointment; and by all the weddings I am the object of the weddings, and I am the knowledge of the weddings and the weddings.

Original:
15.16 Two Purushas there are in this world, the perishable and the imperishable. All beings are 
the perishable and the Kutastha  the unchanging  is called the imperishable.
Translated: 15:16 These are two men in this people: the horror and the letter, all the spirits are the horror, and the letter is called the "coutst".

Original: 15.17 But distinct is the Supreme Purusha called the highest Self, the indestructible Lord Who, pervading the three worlds, sustains them.
Translated: 15:17 But the best man is the only one, who calls God, and who enters into the three peoples, is the unfair God who holds all things.

Original: 15.18 As I transcend the perishable and am even higher than the imperishable, I am declared to be the highest Purusha in the world and in the Vedas.
Translated: 15:18 For I am from the past and better than the letter, so I am famous in the people and in the wedds for the name of the best man.

Original: 15.19 He who, undeluded, knows Me thus as the highest Purusha, he, knowing all, worships Me with his whole being (heart), O Arjuna.
Translated: 15:19 O India! thus, whoever, summaryly, knows me the best man, he becomes all-known and devote me with full spirit, i.e. with full heart.

Original: 15.20 Thus, this most secret science has been taught by Me, O sinless one; on knowing this, a man becomes wise, and all his duties are accomplished, O Arjuna.
Translated: 15:20 O sinful India! thus this great Scripture has been spoken by me, and by knowing it man becomes wise and grateful.

Original: 16.1 The Blessed Lord said  Fearlessness, purity of heart, steadfastness in knowledge and Yoga, almsgiving, control of the senses, sacrifice, study of scriptures, austerity and straightforwardness.
Translated: 16:1 The Lord God said, "Agae, end: purity ofization, a firm position in knowledge use, donation, dam, yeg, स्वाध्याय, tap and arjov."

Original: 16.2 Harmlessness, truth, absence of anger, renunciation, peacefulness, absence of crookedness, compassion towards beings, non-covetousness, gentleness, modesty, absence of fickleness.
Translated: 16.2. unviolence, truth, absence of anger, abandonment, peace, dishonor (not to condemn anyone), mercy to the ghost, alolupta, mardow (commelity), jalousy, imbecility.

Original: 16.3 Vigour, forgiveness, fortitude, purity, absence of hatred, absence of pride  these belong to the one born for a divine state, O Arjuna.
Translated: Oh India! the lack of fast, forgiveness, patience, shutch (pure), adroh and overman (gerv), these are all the signs of the man who has received the divine property.

Original: 16.4 Hypocrisy, arrogance and self-conceit, anger and also harshness and ignorance, belong to one who is born for a demoniacal state, O Partha (Arjuna).
Translated: 16:4 O paths, thumb, mirror, pride, anger, hard speech, and ignorance, all this is a possession.

Original: 16.5 The divine nature is deemed conducive to liberation, and the demoniacal to bondage. Grieve not, O Arjuna, thou art born with divine endowments.
Translated: 16:5 O Pandov, the divine possession has been believed for redemption and the assure possession for bonding; do not regret, for you have obtained the divine possession.

Original: 16.6 There are two types of beings in this world, the divine and the demoniacal; the divine has been described at length; hear from Me, O Arjuna, of the demoniacal.
Translated: 16:6 O Parath, there are two kinds of creation among this people, the goddess and the assur; in them the nature of the gods (the gods) is spoken in detail; now the nature of the assur is spoken: listen to me.

Original: 16.7 The demoniacal know not what to do and what to refrain from; neither purity, nor right conduct nor truth is found in them.
Translated: 16:7 Those who have an assyrial nature do not know the tendency; nor does it know, nor does it have purity in them, nor does it have righteousness, nor does it have truth.

Original: 16.8 They say, "This universe is without truth, without (moral) basis, without a God, brought about by mutual union, with lust for its cause; what else?"
Translated: 16:8 They say that this is worldless, false, and without God, it is derived from the mutual sexual relationship, and what can it be?

Original: 16.9 Holding this view, these ruined souls of small intellect and fierce deeds, come forth as the enemies of the world for its destruction.
Translated: 16:9 Those who have the wise mind of the destruction, the wicked, the wicked, the wicked, the wicked, the wicked, the wicked, the wicked, the wicked.

Original: 16.10 Filled with insatiable desires, full of hypocrisy, pride and arrogance, holding evil ideas through delusion, they work with impure resolves.
Translated: 16.10 In order to shelter the desires that never will be fulfilled, containing demons, values and matters, these people of impure resolutions act in the world, by accepting the wicked misconceptions.

Original: 16.11 Giving themselves over to immeasurable cares ending only with death, regarding gratification of lust as their highest aim, and feeling sure that that is all.
Translated: 16.11 Those who suffer from unremovable concerns that will survive until death and consider toxicity as the ultimate target are not sure that "this is so (truth, joy)."

Original: 16.12 Bound by a hundred ties of hope, given over to lust and anger, they strive to obtain by unlawful means hoards to wealth for sensual enjoyments.
Translated: 16.12 Binding by hundreds of aspirations, these people, under work and anger, try to unfairly gather money to fulfill the subjects.

Original: 16.13 "This has been gained by me today; this desire of mine I shall fuffil; this is mine and this wealth also shall be mine in future."
Translated: 16:13 I have found this today and I will also receive this mindfulness, I have so much wealth and even more wealth will be in the future.

Original: 16.14 "That enemy has been slain by me; and others also I shall slay. I am the lord. I enjoy. I am perfect, powerful and happy."
Translated: 16:14 “This enemy has been killed by me, and the other enemy I will also be killed,” “I am God and I am God,” “I am a proven man,” “I am strong and happy.”

Original: 16.15 "I am rich and born in a noble family. Who else is equal to me? I shall perform sacrifices. I shall give (charity). I shall rejoice," thus deluded by ignorance.
Translated: 16:15 "I am born in righteousness and superiority; who is the other like me?", "I will know", "I will donate", "I will mozzar" - this kind of ignorance they are mozzared.

Original: 16.16 Bewildered by many a fancy, entangled in the snare of delusion, addicted to the gratification of lust, they fall into a foul hell.
Translated: 16:16 Those who have many ways of confusing mind, hunted in the hunt of moh and in subjects, fall into the hunt, unhealthy hell.

Original: 16.17 Self-conceited, stubborn, filled with the pride and intoxication of wealth, they perform sacrifices in name out of ostentation, contrary to scriptural ordinances.
Translated: 16:17 Those who consider themselves the best, those who are possessed of the material of stature, wealth and wealth, without the law of the Scriptures, only by the knowledge of the name of the name of the name of the name of the name of the name of the name of the name.

Original: 16.18 Given over to egoism, power, haughtiness, lust and anger, these malicious people hate Me in their own bodies and in those of others.
Translated: 16:18 Those who persecute self, strength, mirror, work and anger are those who persecute me in their own and in the body of others.

Original: 16.19 Those cruel haters, worst among men in the world, I hurl those evil-doers into the wombs of demons only.
Translated: 16:19 Those who do so, those who do so, those who do so, those who do so, those who do so, those who do so, those who do so, those who do so, those who do so, those who do so, those who do so, those who do so, those who do so, those who do so.

Original: 16.20 Entering into demoniacal wombs and deluded, birth after birth, not attaining Me, they thus fall, O Arjuna, into a condition still lower than that.
Translated: 16:20 O cowboy, they get asuri vagina in the birth of old men, and (thus) they get unacceptable speed without me being received.

Original: 16.21 Triple is the gate of this hell, destructive of the self  lust, anger and greed; therefore one should abandon these three.
Translated: 16.21 Work, anger and lust are the triple doors of self-destruction, so these three must give up.

Original: 16.22 A man who is liberated from these three gates to darkness, O Arjuna, practises what is good for him and thus goes to the Supreme Goal.
Translated: 16:22 O king, the man free from these three doors of hell acts the means of his well-being and thus achieves super speed.

Original: 16.23 He who, having cast aside the ordinances of the scriptures, acts under the impulse of desire, attains not perfection, nor happiness nor the Supreme Goal.
Translated: 16:23 The man who gives up the Scriptures and acts by his will, he does not obtain the proof of perfection, nor pleasure, nor greater speed.

Original: 16.24 Therefore, let the scripture be thy authority in determining what ought to be done and what ought not to be done. Having known what is said in the ordinance of the scriptures, thou shouldst act here in this world.
Translated: 16:24 Therefore the Scriptures are proof to you in the order of duty and deceit, and you should do your works by knowing the Scriptures.

Original: 17.1 Arjuna said  Those who, setting aside the ordinances of the scriptures, perform sacrifice with faith, what is their condition, O Krishna? Is is Sattva, Rajas or Tamas?
Translated: 17:1 And Arjuna said, O Kṛṣṇa, whoever dismisses the Scriptures and worships with respect, what is their position, is it seven, or is it righteous, or is it thamsic?

Original: 17.2 The Blessed Lord said  Threefold is the faith of the embodied, which is inherent in their nature  the Sattvic (pure), the Rajasic (passionate) and the Tamasic (dark). Do thou hear of it.
Translated: 17:2 And the Lord said, Three kinds of natural (unknown) honor of the bodies are: Seventh, Rajic, and Tamasic, you hear it from me.

Original: 17.3 The faith of each is in accordance with his nature, O Arjuna. The man consists of his faith; as a man's faith is, so is he.
Translated: 17:3 O India, the honor of all men is in accordance with their essence, this man is honorable, so the man whose honor is he himself is the same, i.e. whose honor is the same as his shape.

Original: 17.4 The Sattvic or the pure men worship the gods; the Rajasic or the passionate worship the Yakshas and the Rakshasas; the others (the Tamasic or the deluded people) worship the ghosts and the hosts of the nature-spirits.
Translated: 17.4 Seven men worship the gods, and the rich people worship the yucus and the demons, and the other Tamsi peoples and the ghosts.

Original: 17.5 Those men who practise terrific austerities not enjoined by the scriptures, given to hypocrisy and egoism, impelled by the force of lust and attachment.
Translated: 17.5 Those who thap horrors without the Scriptures and are also possessed of dumb, ego, work and wrath.

Original: 17.6 Senseless, torturing all the elements in the body and Me also, Who dwell in the body,  know thou these to be of demonical resolves.
Translated: 17:6 And those who give grate to the flesh and to the one who is among me, those who are unconscious, you know those who are sure.

Original: 17.7 The food also which is dear to each is threefold, as also sacrifice, austerity and almsgiving. Hear thou the distinction of these.
Translated: 17:7 And there are three kinds of food for all men: the same kind of food, the same kind of gift, the same kind of gift, the same kind of gift, the same kind of gift, the same kind of gift, and the same kind of gift.

Original: 17.8 The foods which increase life, purity, strength, health, joy and cheerfulness (good appetite), which are savoury and oleaginous, substantial and agreeable, are dear to the Sattvic (pure) people.
Translated: 17.8. age, truth, strength, health, pleasure and love and sweetened, smooth, stable and pleasant foods, i.e. foods, are favourite to seven men.

Original: 17.9 The foods that are bitter, sour, saline, excessively hot, pungent, dry and burning, are liked by the Rajasic and are productive of pain, grief and disease.
Translated: 17.9. gorgeous, crushed, salty, excessive, sharp (thinking, containing pepper), rough, thirsty, painful, painful and disease-generating factors food substances are loved to the man.

Original: 17.10 That which is state, tasteless, putrid, rotten, refuse and impure, is the food liked by the Tamasic.
Translated: 17:10 Half-picked, unrighteous, unrighteous, basic, high and unrighteous (in the midst) food is loved by the people of Tamas.

Original: 17.11 That sacrifice which is offered by men without desire for reward as enjoined by the ordinance (scripture), with a firm faith that to do so is a duty, is Sattvic or pure.
Translated: 17:11 Whoever has been controlled by the Scriptures, and whoever “this is my duty” is done by those who do not seek fruit, he is the seventh.

Original: 17.12 The sacrifice which is offered, O Arjuna, seeking a reward and for ostentation, know thou that to be a Rajasic Yajna.
Translated: 17:12 O greatest Arjuna, whom the knowledge is made for thumb and for fruit, that knowledge do you consider righteous.

Original: 17.13 They declare that sacrifice to be Tamasic which is contrary to the ordinances of the scriptures, in which no food is distributed, which is devoid of Mantras, gifts and faith.
Translated: 17:13 Those who are without the law of the Scriptures, without the gifts, without the commandments, without the south and without the honour are called thames.

Original: 17.14 Worship of the gods, the twice-born, the teachers and the wise, purity, straightforwardness, celibacy and non-injury are called the austerities of the body.
Translated: 17:14 The prayer of God, the divinity (Brahman), the master and the wise men, the prayer, the shuch, the arjov (Servity), the brahmaty and the non-violence, this is called the body-related tap.

Original: 17.15 Speech which causes no excitement, truthful, pleasant and beneficial, the practice of the study of the Vedas, are called austerity of speech.
Translated: 17:15 The word (speech) which does not generate awakening, which is loving, pleasant and truthful, and the practice of the wedds is called the vocal (speech) topp.

Original: 17.16 Serenity of mind, good-heartedness, self-control, purity of nature  this is called mental austerity.
Translated: 17.16 The pleasure of the mind, the pleasure, the silence of self-satisfaction and the purity of the end: this all the mind is called thap.

Original: 17.17 This threefold austerity, practised by steadfast men, with the utmost faith, desiring no reward, they call Sattvic.
Translated: 17:17 The trivial taup which was done with great honour by men who did not seek fruit, is called seven.

Original: 17.18 The austerity which is practised with the object of gaining good reception, honour and worship, and with hypocrisy, is here said to be Rajasic, unstable and transitory.
Translated: 17:18 Those that thap is done for truth, honor and worship, or only by dumb, the uncertain and momentary thap is called here Rajas.

Original: 17.19 That austerity which is practised out of a foolish notion, with self-torture, or for the purpose of destroying another, is declared to be Tamasic.
Translated: 17:19 Whoever is made to sacrifice himself or to destroy others, he is called tooth.

Original: 17.20 That gift which is given to one who does nothing in return, knowing it to be a duty to give in a fit place and time to a worthy person, that gift is held to be Sattvic.
Translated: 17:20 "Giving is a duty" - by this sense which is given to a (worthy) character (person) by seeing the day, which does not expect any help, the gift is considered seventh.

Original: 17.21 And, that gift which is given with a view to receive something in return, or looking for a reward, or reluctantly, is held to be Rajasic.
Translated: 17:21 And which gifts are given unfortunately and for the purpose of mutilation or with the desire of fruit, the gift has been considered reward.

Original: 17.22 The gift that is given at a wrong place and time, to unworthy persons, without respect or with insult is declared to be Tamasic.
Translated: 17.22 The donation which is granted to the corrupt in unworthy country, unjustly, or in detrimental manner, the donation is considered to be thames.

Original: 17.23 "Om Tat Sat": This has been declared to be the triple designation of Brahman. By that were created formerly, the Brahmanas, the Vedas and the sacrifices.
Translated: 17:23 So is this the trivial direction of the universe called; from it in the adicle are made brahman, wade, and knowledge.

Original: 17.24 Therefore, with the utterance of "Om" are the acts of sacrifice, gift and austerity as enjoined in the scriptures, always begun by the students of Brahman.
Translated: 17.24 Therefore, the writings of the brahmians replicate the actions of yogging, donation, and toap always begin with the pronunciation of ounkar.

Original: 17.25 Uttering ï1Tatï1, without aiming at the fruits, are the acts of sacrifice and austerity and the various acts of gifts performed by the seekers of liberation.
Translated: 17:25 By the expression of the word 'tat', without having the will of fruit, the musulmans do various works, to know, to give, and so on.

Original: 17.26 The word ï1Satï1 is used in the sense of reality and of goodness; and so also, O Arjuna, the word ï1Satï1 is used in the sense of an auspicious act.
Translated: 17:26 O patter! the word 'SAT' is used in the truth and in the sadness, and the word 'SAT' is used in the praised (best, happy) karma.

Original: 17.27 Steadfastness in sacrifice, austerity and gift, is also called 'Sat' and also action in connection with these (or for the sake of the Supreme) is called 'Sat'.
Translated: 17:27 And in the knowledge, and in the compassion, and in the gift, and in the work done for it, and in the work done for it, and in the work done for it, and in the work done for it, and in the work done for it, and in the work done for it.

Original: 17.28 Whatever is sacrificed, given or performed, and whatever austerity is practised without faith, it is called 'Asat', O Arjuna; it is naught here or hereafter (after death).
Translated: 17:28 O Parath, what is done unrighteously by knowledge, donation, thapping, and karma, it is called unrighteous; it is neither beneficial in this people nor after death.

Original: 18.1 Arjuna said  I desire to know severally, O mighty-armed, the essence or truth of renunciation, O Hrishikesa, as also of abandonment, O slayer of Kesi.
Translated: 18:1 And Arjuna said, O great, O Harishikesh, O Keshinishudan, I want to separate the intelligence of sanity and abandonment.

Original: 18.2 The Blessed Lord said  The sages understand Sannyasa to be the renunciation of action with desire; the wise declare the abandonment of the fruits of all actions as Tyaga.
Translated: 18:2 And the Lord said, (some) poets (pondit) people understand the abandonment of the works of work as "sanyas" and the thoughtful people call the abandonment of the fruits of all the works "thag".

Original: 18.3 Some philosophers declare that actions should be abandoned as an evil; while others (declare) that acts of sacrifice, gift and austerity should not be relinished.
Translated: 18.3 Some menishes say that all the works are abandoned because they are guilty; and others say that knowledge, gifts, and thaperforms are not abandoned.

Original: 18.4 Hear from Me the conclusion or the final truth about this abandonment, O best of the Bharatas; abandonment, verily, O best of men, has been declared to be of three kinds.
Translated: 18:4 O greatest, listen to my judgment concerning that abandonment; O greatest man, this abandonment is said in three kinds.

Original: 18.5 Acts of sacrifice, gift and austerity should not be abandoned, but should be performed; sacrifice, gift and also austerity are the purifiers of the wise.
Translated: 18:5 The knowledge, the gift, and the purification of the work are not denial, but it is a duty; the knowledge, the gift, and the purification of the work are the purification of the men.

Original: 18.6 But even these actions should be performed leaving aside attachment and the desire for rewards, O Arjuna; this is My certain and best conviction.
Translated: 18:6 O paths, these works should be abandoned, fruit and asset, this is not the best that I have made.

Original: 18.7 Verily the renunciation of obligatory action is not proper; the abandonment of the same from delusion is declared to be Tamasic.
Translated: 18.7 The abandonment of the determined karma is not righteous; the abandonment of it is called “tamas abandonment”.

Original: 18.8 He who abandons action on account of the fear of bodily trouble (because it is painful), does not obtain the merit of renunciation by doing such Rajasic renunciation.
Translated: 18:8 Those who give up the karma by fear of physical suffering, considering it a sadness, the man does not obtain the fruit of abandonment by giving up that noble abandonment.

Original: 18.9 Whatever obligatory action is done, O Arjuna, merely because it ought to be done, abandoning attachment and also the desire for reward, that renunciation is regarded as Sattvic (pure).
Translated: 18:9 O Arjuna, “to do is duty” in this sense which is abandoned by the prescribed person and fruit, the same seventh abandonment has been considered.

Original: 18.10 The man of renunciation, pervaded by purity, intelligent, and with his doubts cut asunder, does not hate a disagreeable work nor is he attached to an agreeable one.
Translated: 18:10 And whoever does not deceive with the unbearable work, and does not deceive with the unbearable work, he is the full-fledged man, the unbearable, the knowledgeable, and the unbearable.

Original: 18.11 Verily, it is not possible for an embodied being to abandon actions entirely; but he who relinishes the rewards of actions is verily called a man of renunciation.
Translated: 18:11 For it is not possible for the body-driven man to give up special works, therefore the man who has the carmaffle to give up is called the man to give up.

Original: 18.12 The threefold fruit of action (evil, good and mixed) accrues after death to the non-abandoners, but never to the abandoners.
Translated: 18:12 These trivial fruits of the good, unhappy and mixed works only get to the unrighteous people after their death, but not to the humble men.

Original: 18.13 Learn from Me, O mighty-armed Arjuna, these five causes as declared in the Sankhya system for the accomplishment of all actions.
Translated: 18:13 Oh great, for the proof of all the works these five reasons are stated in theory of statistics, which you know better than me.

Original: 18.14 The seat (body), the doer, the various senses, the different functions of various sorts, and the presiding deity, also, the fifth.
Translated: 18:14 The supremacy (the body), the work, the diversity, the diversity, the diversity and the separation of the earth, and the fifth is the god.

Original: 18.15 Whatever action a man performs with his body, speech and mind  whether right or the reverse  these five are its causes.
Translated: 18:15 Those are five reasons for the man who, by his body, his voice and his mind, does a righteous (just) or contrary (unjust) work.

Original: 18.16 Now, such being the case, verily he who  owing to untrained understanding  looks upon his Self, which is isolated, as the agent, he of perverted intelligence, sees not.
Translated: 18:16 Now in this situation which men, because of their uncultured wisdom, consider only the pure spirit to be a worker, he does not see the evil man.

Original:
18.17 He who is free from the egoistic notion, whose intelligence is not tainted (by good or evil), 
though he slays these people, he slayeth not, nor is he bound (by the action).
Translated: 18:17 The man who has no sense of selfishness, and the wisdom is not covered by anyone, the man, even by killing all these people, does not die, nor is he bound.

Original: 18.18 Knowledge, the knowable and the knower form the threefold impulse to action; the organ, the action and the agent form the threefold basis of action.
Translated: 18:18 Knowledge, knowledge and knowledge are these trivial karma provokers, and, karan, karma. karta are these trivial karma collection.

Original: 18.19 Knowledge, action and actor are declared in the science of the Gunas (Sankhya philosophy) to be of three kinds only, according to the distinction of the Gunas. Of these also, hear duly.
Translated: 18:19 And the knowledge, and the work, and the work, and the skill of the qualities, have been trivially spoken in the Statistics; and you shall listen to them from Me.

Original: 18.20 That by which one sees the one indestructible Reality in all beings, not separate in all the separate beings  know thou that knowledge to be Sattvic.
Translated: 18:20 By the knowledge of which man sees in all the spirits in different shapes an inseparable and immortal shape, you know that knowledge seven.

Original: 18.21 But that knowledge which sees in all beings various entities of distinct kinds as different from one another  know thou that knowledge to be Rajasic.
Translated: 18:21 By the knowledge by which man separates feelings in all spirits, you know that knowledge.

Original: 18.22 But that which clings to one single effect as if it were the whole, without reason, without foundation in Truth, and trivial  that is declared to be Tamasic.
Translated: 18:22 And the knowledge by which man becomes assured in a work, as if it was a perfect thing, and the knowledge which is untouched, untouched, and compressed, is a thumb.

Original: 18.23 An action which is ordained, which is free from attachment, and which is done without love or hatred by one who is not desirous of any reward  that action is declared to be Sattvic.
Translated: 18:23 Whoever is determined and preserved, and has been made by a man who does not want fruit, without any wrath, he is called Seventh.

Original: 18.24 But that action which is done by one longing for the fulfilment of desires or gain with egoism or with much effort  that is declared to be Rajasic (passionate).
Translated: 18:24 And the work that is hard and is done by a man who desires fruit, selfish, is called the work.

Original: 18.25 That action which is undertaken from delusion, without a regard for the conseences, loss, injury and (one's own) ability  that is declared to be Tamasic (dark).
Translated: 18:25 Whose karma result, loss, violence, and sarmthy (Purushum) are not considered, but are only begun with mohvash, it is called karma thams.

Original: 18.26 An agent who is free from attachment, non-egoistic, endowed with firmness and enthusiasm, and unaffected by success or failure, is called Sattvic (pure).
Translated: 18:26 Whoever does not preserve, without selfishness, with patience and enthusiasm and remains unwilling in the proof of work (success) and in the failure (success), he is called the worker seventh.

Original: 18.27 Passionate, desiring to obtain the reward of actions, greedy, cruel, impure, moved by joy and sorrow, such an agent is said to be Rajasic (passionate).
Translated: 18.27 Ragi, the desirable of karmaffle, loudi, violent nature, unclean and harshok, calls the worker Rajas.

Original: 18.28 Unsteady, vulgar, unbending, cheating, malicious, lazy, desponding and procrastinating  such an agent is called Tamasic.
Translated: 18.28 Unused, natural, stable, shast, natural, lazy, toxic and long-sucher is called thames.

Original: 18.29 Hear thou the threefold division of intellect and firmness according to the Gunas, as I declare them fully and distinctly, O Arjuna.
Translated: 18:29 O righteousness, by me unparalleled, and separately, listen to the trivial distinction of wisdom and righteousness arising from qualities.

Original: 18.30 The intellect which knows the path of work and renunciation, what ought to be done and what ought not to be done, fear and fearlessness, bondage and liberation  that intellect is Sattvic (pure), O Arjuna.
Translated: 18:30 O Parath, who wisdom knows the tendency and the negligence, the work and the worklessness, the fear and the shame and the bond and the salvation, he is the wisdom seventh.

Original: 18.31 That, by which one wrongly understands Dharma and Adharma and also what ought to be done and what ought not to be done  that intellect, O Arjuna, is Rajasic (passionate).
Translated: 18:31 O Parath, by the wisdom by which man does not know the religion and the unrighteousness and the duty and the unrighteousness, he is the righteous of the wisdom.

Original: 18.32 That, which, enveloped in darkness, sees Adharma as Dharma and all things perverted  that intellect, O Arjuna, is Tamasic (dark).
Translated: 18:32 O paths, whoever is driven by thams (unknowledge blind: car), whoever believes the wisdom of unrighteousness and knows all things in the opposite way, is the wisdom of thams.

Original: 18.33 The unwavering firmness by which, through Yoga, the functions of the mind, the life-force and the senses are restrained  that firmness, O Arjuna, is Sattvic (pure).
Translated: 18.33 is a seventh.

Original: 18.34 But that, O Arjuna, by which, on account of attachment and desire for reward, one holds fast to Dharma (duty), enjoyment of pleasures and earning of wealth  that firmness, O Arjuna, is Rajasic (passionate).
Translated: 18:34 O earth son Arjuna, the desirable man of karma, from the excess of persuasion by which the religion, meaning, and work (this three men) is possessed, is the persuasion of persuasion.

Original: 18.35 That, by which a stupid man does not abandon sleep, fear, grief, despair and also conceit  that firmness, O Arjuna, is Tamasic.
Translated: 18:35 Oh patter! the unconscious man by whose perception he does not give up the dreams, fears, sadness, poison and matter, he is the patterns.

Original: 18.36 And now hear from Me, O Arjuna, of the threefold pleasure, in which one rejoices by practice and surely comes to the end of pain.
Translated: 18:36 Now you hear from me the trivial pleasure, in which [the righteous man] runs with practice and achieves the end of suffering (where his suffering ends).

Original: 18.37 That which is like poison at first but in the end like nectar  that happiness is declared to be Sattvic, born of the purity of one's own mind due to Self-realisation.
Translated: 18:37 Whoever happiness is like the first (in the beginning) poison, but in the result is like the immortal, he is called happiness generated from the offering of self-science.

Original: 18.38 That happiness which arises from the contact of the sense-organs with the objects, which is at first like nectar, and in the end like poison  that is declared to be Rajasic.
Translated: 18:38 Whoever arises from coincidence of pleasure subjects and senses, he is first like the immortal, but in the result is toxic comparable, he is called pleasure.

Original: 18.39 That happiness which at first as well as in the seel deludes the self, and which arises from sleep, indolence and heedlessness  that is declared to be Tamasic.
Translated: 18:39. whoever pleases the soul in the beginning and also in the result, he is called the pleasant times that are generated from humiliation, humiliation and praise.

Original: 18.40 There is no being on earth or again in heaven among the gods, that is liberated from the three alities born of Nature.
Translated: 18:40 There is no such creature on earth or among the gods of heaven which is free from these three qualities of nature.

Original: 18.41 Of Brahmanas, Kshatriyas and Vaisyas, as also of Sudras, O Arjuna, the duties are distributed according to the alities born of their own nature.
Translated: 18:41 O Lord, the charmes of brahmans, pervers, vasks and shuders are divided according to the qualities arising from nature.

Original: 18.42 Serenity, self-restraint, austerity, purity, forgiveness and also uprightness, knowledge, realisation and belief in God are the duties of the Brahmanas, born of (their own) nature.
Translated: 18.42 Sham, Dam, Tape, Shoch, Oracle, Arjov, Knowledge, Science and Reality – these are the natural karma of Brahman.

Original: 18.43 Prowess, splendour, firmness, dexterity and also not fleeing from battle, generosity and lordliness are the duties of the Kshatriyas, born of (their own) nature.
Translated: 18.43 Shura, Tej, Dharti, Daku (Daku), Don’t Escape from War, Don and God’s Passion (Swami Passion) – all of these are the natural works of the Perpetual.

Original: 18.44 Agriculture, cattle-rearing and trade are the duties of the Vaisya (merchant), born of (their own) nature; and action consisting of service is the duty of the Sudra (servant-class), born of (their own) nature.
Translated: 18.44. agriculture, gaupalan and commerce - these are the natural karma of the vals, and the natural karma of the shutter is familiarity, i.e. serving.

Original: 5.10 He who does actions, offering them to Brahman, and abandoning attachment, is not tainted by sin, just as a lotus-leaf is not tainted by water.
Translated: 5.10 Whoever man sacrifices all the works in the universe and gives up the asset, he shall not be liable of sin like the leaf of the man's camel.

Original: 18.46 He from Whom all the beings have evolved and by Whom all this is pervaded  worshipping Him with his own duty, man attains perfection.
Translated: 18:46. from whom the temptation of the spirit is created, and from whom the whole world is spread, man is obtained by worship by the self-righteousness of the spirit.

Original: 18.47 Better is one's own duty (though) destitute of merits, than the duty of another well performed. He who does the duty ordained by his own nature incurs no sin.
Translated: 18:47 And the worthless self is better than the worthless self; for the man does not receive sin by doing the worthless work.

Original: 18.48 One should not abandon, O Arjuna, the duty to which one is born, though faulty; for, all undertakings are enveloped by evil, as fire by smoke.
Translated: 18:48 O Kantey, even if you are guilty, you should not give up the self-made work; for all the work is diverted by guilty, like smoke from fire.

Original: 18.49 He whose intellect is unattached everywhere, who has subdued his self, from whom desire has fled,  he by renunciation, attains the supreme state of freedom from action.
Translated: 18.49 The man with all-asset-free wisdom, who is sphered and jithatma, obtains the ultimate natural proof by sanity.

Original: 18.50 Learn from Me in brief, O Arjuna, how he who has attained perfection reaches Brahman (the Eternal), that supreme state of knowledge.
Translated: 18:50 How the man receiving the proof receives the universe, and the supreme faithfulness of knowledge you also know from me in short.

Original: 18.51 Endowed with a pure intellect, controlling the self by firmness, relinishing sound and other objects and abandoning attraction and hatred.
Translated: 18.51 With pure wisdom, make self-satisfaction with patience, give up the words and subjects and give up the righteousness.

Original: 18.52 Dwelling in solitude, eating but little, with speech, body and mind subdued, always engaged in meditation and concentration, resorting to dispassion.
Translated: 18:52. distinctive servant, shortwasher (mithahari) who has sanctified his body, voice and mind, always engaged in the practice of meditation on expectation and varagya.

Original: 18.53 Having abandoned egoism, strength, arrogance, desire, anger and covetousness, and free from the notion of 'mine' and peaceful,  he is fit for becoming Brahman.
Translated: 18.53. by giving up self, strength, mirror, work, anger and glory, a quiet man becomes worthy of achieving the universe.

Original: 18.54 Becoming Brahman, serene in the Self, he neither grieves nor desires, the same to all beings, he obtains supreme devotion to Me.
Translated: 18:54 The brahman (who has become a seeking brahman), a man with a pleasant mind does not desire, nor sorrow, and is equal to all ghosts, he receives my supreme devotion.

Original: 18.55 By devotion he knows Me in truth, what and who I am; then having known Me in truth, he forthwith enters into the Supreme.
Translated: 18:55 Through his devotion he knows how much I am and what I am, and immediately after knowing he enters into me, that is, he becomes a form.

Original: 18.56 Doing all actions always having taken refuge in Me, by My grace he obtains the eternal indestructible state of being.
Translated: 18:56 And whoever does all the works, and always does all the things, he will obtain the eternal, unfair position by my grace.

Original: 18.57 Mentally renouncing all actions in Me, having Me as the highest goal, resorting to the Yoga of discrimination do thou ever fix thy mind on Me.
Translated: 18:57. by the mind all the works shall be sanated in me, and you shall be the refuge of the wisdom, and you shall be the constant mankind.

Original: 18.58 Fixing thy mind on Me, thou shalt by My grace overcome all obstacles; but if from egoism thou wilt not hear Me, thou shalt perish.
Translated: 18:58 And with my grace you will overcome all the difficulties; and if you do not listen to selfishness, then you will be destroyed.

Original: 18.59 If, filled with egoism, thou thinkest: "I will not fight", vain is this, thy resolve; Nature will compel thee.
Translated: 18:59 And you who think, I will not fight, this is a falsehood for you, for the nature will tend you.

Original: 18.60 O Arjuna, bound by thy own Karma (action) born of thy own nature, that which from delusion thou wishest not to do, even that thou shalt do helplessly.
Translated: 18:60 O ye whoever, you are bound by your natural works, and you will do the work that you do not want to do, and you will be wicked.

Original: 18.61 The Lord dwells in the hearts of all beings, O Arjuna, causing all beings, by His illusive power, to revolve as if mounted on a machine.
Translated: 18:61 O Arjuna, all the ghosts that rush on the edge, God is in the heart of the ghost, which runs from His Maya.

Original: 18.62 Fly unto Him for refuge with all thy being, O Arjuna; by His grace thou shalt obtain supreme peace (and) the eternal abode.
Translated: 18:62 O India, go in the refuge of the same (God) with all your heart; with his gift you will obtain the ultimate peace and eternal place.

Original: 18.63 Thus has wisdom, more secret than secrecy itself, been declared unto thee by Me; having reflected over it fully, then act as thou wishest.
Translated: 18:63 So I have told you greater knowledge than all the secrets; after you have made full consideration of it, have your desire, so do you.

Original: 18.64 Hear thou again My supreme word, most secret of all; because thou art dearly beloved of Me, I will tell thee what is good.
Translated: 18:64 Again, once you hear from me the ultimate word in all the heavens; you are very loved by me, so I will tell you the word of your interest.

Original: 18.65 Fix thy mind on Me, by devoted to Me, sacrifice to Me, bow down to Me. Thou shalt come even to Me; truly do I promise unto thee, (for) thou art dear to Me.
Translated: 18:65 Be your worshippers, your worshippers, and my worshippers, and greet me; so you will receive me; this I promise you the truth, for you are my beloved.

Original: 18.66 Abandoning all duties, take refuge in Me alone: I will liberate thee from all sins; grieve not.
Translated: 18:66 By giving up all religions, come in one of my shelter; I will free you from all sins, and do not regret.

Original: 18.67 This is never to be spoken by thee to one who is devoid of austerities or devotion, nor to one who does not render service or who does not desire to listen, nor to one who cavils at Me.
Translated: 18:67 This knowledge should not be said to a man who is untouched, nor to a man who is untouched, nor to a man who is untouched, nor to a man who is untouched with me, that is, he sees fault in me.

Original: 18.68 He who with supreme devotion to Me will teach this supreme secret to My devotees, shall doubtlessly come to Me.
Translated: 18:68 Whoever preaches this great knowledge to my servants by loving me, he will surely receive me.

Original: 18.69 Nor is there any among men who does dearer service to Me, nor shall there be another on earth dearer to Me than he.
Translated: 18:69 There is no one among men who will do more than it, and no one more than it will be my beloved on this earth.

Original: 18.70 And he who will study this sacred dialogue of ours, by him I shall have been worshipped by the sacrifice of wisdom,  such is My conviction.
Translated: 18:70 Whoever man will read this religious dialogue between us two, by him I will be worshipped by the wise, that is not me.

Original: 18.71 Also the man who hears this, full of faith and free from malice, he, too, liberated, shall attain to the happy worlds of those of righteous deeds.
Translated: 18:71 And whoever hears him, and whoever is wicked, and whoever is wicked, and whoever is wicked, and whoever is wicked, and whoever is wicked, and whoever is wicked, and whoever is wicked, and whoever is wicked, and whoever is wicked, and whoever is wicked.

Original: 18.72 Has this been heard, O Arjuna, with one-pointed mind? Has the delusion of thy ignorance been destroyed, O Dhananjaya?
Translated: 18:72 O Pharat, did you listen to it (to my prophecy) with concentration, and O wise man, was your ignorance, which was born, completely destroyed?

Original: 18.73 Arjuna said  Destroyed is my delusion as I have gained my knowledge (memory) through Thy grace, O Krishna. I remain freed from doubts. I will act according to Thy word.
Translated: 18:7 And Arjuna said, O unclean, my mouth has been destroyed by your grace, and I have received a memory; now I have become unclean, and I will follow your word.

Original: 18.74 Sanjaya said  Thus I have heard this wonderful dialogue between Krishna and the high-souled Arjuna, which causes the hair to stand on end.
Translated: Sanjay said — thus I described this wonderful and exciting dialogue between Godvassudev and Mahatma Arjuna.

Original: 18.75 Through the grace of Vyasa I have heard this supreme and most secret Yoga direct from Krishna, the Lord of Yoga, Himself declaring it.
18.76 O King, remembering this wonderful and holy dialogue between Krishna and Arjuna, I rejoice again and again.
Translated: 18:76 O Rajan, I am repeatedly rejoiced by remembering this wonderful and purely (holy) dialogue between God and Arjuna.

Original: 18.77 And, remembering again and again, also that most wonderful form of Hari, great is my wonder, O King; and I rejoice again and again.
Translated: 18.77 O Rajan, I am great to recall the very wonderful form of Mr. Hari, and I am repeatedly rejoicing.

Original: 18.78 Wherever is Krishna, the Lord of Yoga; wherever is Arjuna, the wielder of the bow; there are prosperity, victory, happiness and firm policy; such is my conviction.
Translated: 18:78 Where the Yogashv is Sriकृष्ण and where the aristotle is Arjuna there is Mr, Victory, Divorce and Polar Policy, that is not me.
